author: Governor David Ige
title: #HurricaneLane remains a Category 4 storm with winds near 145 mph; Hawaii Island seeing impacts from storm\'s outer bands. A Hurricane Warning is in effect for #Oahu, #Maui County and #Hawaii County. A Hurricane Watch is in effect for #Kauai County.  Maximum sustained winds remain near 145 mph (230 km/h) with higher gusts. Lane is a powerful category 4 hurricane. Some weakening is  forecast during the next few days, but Lane is expected to remain a hurricane as it approaches the islands. Hurricane-force winds extend outward up to 40 miles (65 km) from the center and tropical-storm-force winds extend outward up to 140 miles (220 km).  WIND: Tropical storm conditions are expected on portions of the Big Island beginning early Thursday morning, with hurricane conditions expected in some areas Thursday afternoon or Thursday night.Tropical storm conditions are expected to begin over portions of Maui county on Thursday, with hurricane conditions expected in some areas Thursday night into Friday. Tropical storm conditions are expected to begin on Oahu late Thursday night, with hurricane conditions expected Friday into Friday night. RAINFALL: Rain bands from Hurricane Lane will continue to gradually overspread the Hawaiian Islands tonight and Thursday. Excessive rainfall associated with Lane is expected to affect portions of the Hawaiian Islands from late today into the weekend. This could lead to major flash flooding and landslides. Lane is expected to produce total rain accumulations of 10 to 15 inches with localized amountsin excess of 20 inches over the Hawaiian Islands. SURF: As Lane is slow-moving, large swells generated by Lane will severely impact the Hawaiian Islands over the next couple of days. These swells will produce very large and likely damaging surf along exposed west and south facing shorelines. STORM SURGE: The combination of a dangerous storm surge and large breaking waves will raise water levels by as much as 2 to 4 feet above normal tide levels along south and west facing shores near the center of Lane. The surge will be accompanied by large and destructive waves. Track Lane at http://www.prh.noaa.gov/hnl/Stay safe.

author: Governor David Ige
title: Request for a Presidential Disaster Declaration for the State of Hawai‚Äòi has been approved for Hurricane Lane. See notice of approval at http://bit.ly/2Px3dpW. We are grateful to the President and FEMA Federal Emergency Management Agency for the swift approval of our request as our state braces for the severe weather ahead. The approval of the Presidential Disaster Declaration means that Hawai‚Äòi will have quick and efficient access to federal resources in the wake of Hurricane Lane, as our communities and residents recover from any damage and losses caused by the storm. The declaration authorizes the Department of Homeland Security and the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) to provide appropriate assistance for emergency measures required to save lives and to protect property and public health and safety, or to lessen or avert the threat of a catastrophe. Earlier today, I held a briefing at the State Capitol offices to warn residents and visitors that hurricane conditions are unpredictable and to urge people to take every precaution to protect their health and safety. Details: http://bit.ly/2PxbutZ#HurricaneLane #HIGov #HInews #Lane

title: After 2 hours on the phone with NCL, I was told that the companies policy is that I must choose between flying my family into a very dangerous hurricane Lane or losing the 1000\'s of dollars we have invested in this vacation. I think is is wildly unreasonable for an organization to ask families to make this choice. I was only asking for the option to sail on a different date. Lane was the lead story on GMA today. The Governor of HI saying it is extremely dangerous and asking people to take it seriously and take shelter. Schools are closed for the week. 20" of rain, flash floods, 150 MPH winds, 25\' waves and storm surge. All that and NCL continues to say that the ship is still set to sail on schedule Saturday the 25th. We won\'t be joining NCL again.

author: Governor David Ige
title: Get updates on Hawai\'i Department of Transportation\'s newly added page for #HurricaneLane at http://hidot.hawaii.gov/hurricane-lane/Here\'s the latest:As of Wednesday, Aug. 22, 2018, we are announcing the following:-No special use (contraflow) or Zipper lane operations for Thursday, Aug. 23 and Friday, Aug. 24.-Use caution on coastal roads and roads prone to flooding/high surf, such as Akoni Pule Highway on Hawaii Island and Honoapiilani Highway in the Ukumehame/Olowalu area.-Use caution on roads prone to landslides/rock falls as Kuhio Highway north of Waikoko and Pali Highway at the tunnels. We will be closing Kailua-bound lanes of Pali Highway Thursday, Aug. 23 at 8 p.m. Local access to Wainiha/Haena via Kuhio Highway will run on the Sunday/Holiday schedule until Thursday, Aug. 23 at 11 p.m. These closures are to ensure the safety of drivers. After the storm passes we will assess the routes prior to opening.
description: Get updates on Hawai\'i Department of Transportation\'s newly added page for #HurricaneLane at http://hidot.hawaii.gov/hurricane-lane/Here\'s the latest:As of Wednesday, Aug. 22, 2018, we are announcing the following:-No special use (contraflow) or Zipper lane operations for Thursday, Aug. 23 and Friday, Aug. 24.-Use caution on coastal roads and roads prone to flooding/high surf, such as Akoni Pule Highway on Hawaii Island and Honoapiilani Highway in the Ukumehame/Olowalu area.-Use caution on roads prone to landslides/rock falls as Kuhio Highway north of Waikoko and Pali Highway at the tunnels. We will be closing Kailua-bound lanes of Pali Highway Thursday, Aug. 23 at 8 p.m. Local access to Wainiha/Haena via Kuhio Highway will run on the Sunday/Holiday schedule until Thursday, Aug. 23 at 11 p.m. These closures are to ensure the safety of drivers. After the storm passes we will assess the routes prior to opening.

author: Governor David Ige
title: Hawaii PUBLIC SCHOOLS and Hawaii State Department of Education (HIDOE) offices STATEWIDE will be closed Thursday and Friday as Hurricane Lane approaches the islands as a powerful Category 4 storm. HIDOE schools and offices will reopen on Monday, Aug. 27, unless otherwise noted. The cancellation of all HIDOE after-school activities and programs, including interscholastic athletic events and After-School Plus (A+) Programs statewide, remains in effect through the weekend. More: http://bit.ly/2w7n8Dv#HurricaneLane #HIGov #HInews

author: Governor David Ige
title: I signed a memorandum granting non-essential state employees on O‚Äòahu and Kaua‚Äòi administrative leave as the state prepares for severe weather resulting from Hurricane Lane. State offices on O‚Äòahu and Kaua‚Äòi will be closed on Thursday, Aug. 23, 2018 through Friday, Aug. 24, 2018. Non-essential workers affected by the office closures should not report to work and will be granted administrative leave.However, employees who fall into one of the following categories are required to report to work, unless it is determined that the employee can be excused:‚Ä¢ Departmental Disaster/Emergency Coordinators‚Ä¢ Disaster Response Workers‚Ä¢ Employees whose work involves continuing crucial operations/services, such as hospital workers, correctional workers, etc.All other employees should not report to work on Thursday, Aug. 23 and Friday, Aug. 24, 2018.Memorandum: http://bit.ly/2LjUcgj#HurricaneLane #HIGov #HINews

author: Governor David Ige
title: This is the latest update from the Civil Defense hurricane as of Wednesday, August 22 at 10:00 in the morning. The Hurricane Warning issued by the Central Pacific Hurricane Center continues for Hawaii County. A Hurricane Warning is issued when hurricane conditions of damaging winds, damaging surf, and flooding rains are possible within 36 hours. The Central Pacific Hurricane Center reports as of 8:00 am that Hurricane Lane is a category 4 hurricane located approximately 305 miles S of Kailua-Kona with sustained winds of 155 mph, moving WNW at approximately 8 mph. If this movement continues, Hurricane Lane is projected to pass west of Hawaii Island commencing early Thursday.Due to the Hurricane Warning, the following advisories have been issued:‚Ä¢  A high surf warning is in effect for west facing shores of Ka‚Äôu and Kona. ‚Ä¢  Residents in low lying areas of Ka‚Äôu and Kona subject to wave impacts must take necessary precautions to protect life and property due to dangerous storm surge and large waves. ‚Ä¢  A flash flood watch is in effect for the island of Hawaii. Do expect possible heavy rain leading to flash flooding.‚Ä¢  Hurricane force winds are possible on the west side of the island from South Point to north Kohala. The remainder of the island could experience tropical storm force winds. Due to the Hurricane Warning, the following closures are in effect:‚Ä¢  All schools and the University of Hawaii campuses are closed until further notice.‚Ä¢  All beach parks, from South Point north to Kohala, are closed until further notice. All pavilion and camping permits for these parks have been cancelled.‚Ä¢  South Point Road from the Kamaoa Road junction to South Point is closed to all traffic.‚Ä¢  All County offices and facilities are operational, including transfer stations and landfills. All residents should review preparedness plans and take early precautionary measures at this time. The Division of Boating and Ocean Recreation (DOBOR) advises all boat owners in unprotected harbors from Milolii to Mahukona to take all measures to secure their vessels. This includes removal, if possible. Complete all actions before nightfall. The Department of Education, in coordination with the American Red Cross and Hawaii County Parks and Recreation, have identified shelters in all districts that will be opened if necessary. You will be notified if any of the shelters are opened.Civil Defense is monitoring Hurricane Lane and will keep you informed of any changes that may affect your safety.  Thank you and have a safe day. This is your Hawaii County Civil Defense Agency.

author: Governor David Ige
title: IMPORTANT UPDATE (7:00 PM AUGUST 21):Hurricane Lane has strengthened to a category-5 hurricane. A Hurricane Warning is in effect for:‚Ä¢ Hawaii County A Hurricane Watch is in effect for:‚Ä¢ Maui County...including the islands of Maui, Lanai, Molokai and, Kahoolawe‚Ä¢ Oahu A Hurricane Warning means that hurricane conditions are expected somewhere within the warning area. A warning is typically issued 36 hours before the anticipated first occurrence of tropical-storm-force winds, conditions that make outside preparations difficult or dangerous. Preparations to protect life and property should be rushed to completion. A Hurricane Watch means that hurricane conditions are possible within the watch area. A watch is typically issued 48 hours before the anticipated first occurrence of tropical-storm-force winds, conditions that make outside preparations difficult or dangerous.ORIGINAL POST (8:30 AM AUGUST 21):Hawaii is bracing for the possible arrival of Hurricane Lane over the next couple days. The National Weather Service says this major hurricane is expected to turn toward the Hawaiian Islands on Wednesday.This powerful cyclone has again strengthened to a category-4 hurricane, with maximum sustained winds of 155 mph. As of 8 a.m. today, it is 450 miles south-southeast of Kailua-Kona and 605 miles southeast of Honolulu, traveling toward the islands. Hurricane Lane may bring tropical-storm-force winds to parts of Hawaii as early as Wednesday morning. Tropical cyclones like Hurricane Lane can bring high winds, heavy rain, large and pounding waves, and even king tides along the coast. Major flooding and damaging surf can happen even if the eye of the storm doesn‚Äôt pass over the islands. Make sure you are prepared for Hurricane Lane and other natural disasters, with a family emergency plan and an emergency kit (with enough food, water, medication, and other essentials to last at least 14 days). To find out more information about emergency preparedness, as well as to keep up to date with Hurricane Lane, visit our Current Issues & Advisories page on Hurricane Lane: http://health.hawaii.gov/prepare/current-issues-and-advisories/hurricane-lane/Stay informed with the latest news by monitoring local news broadcasts (radio, TV, or Internet) and by signing up for local emergency notification systems at the following webpages:‚Ä¢ County of Hawaii: countyofhawaii.bbcportal.com‚Ä¢ City & County of Honolulu: hnl.info/alerts/login.php ‚Ä¢ County of Kauai: countyofkauai.bbcportal.com‚Ä¢ County of Maui: www.co.maui.hi.us/list.aspx

author: Governor David Ige
title: Based on the scientific information and expertise available, Hawai‚Äòi is in danger of being significantly impacted by Hurricane Lane, whether or not the hurricane directly hits the state. The counties of Hawai‚Äòi, Maui, Kalawao, Kaua‚Äòi and the City and County of Honolulu are in danger of experiencing high winds, heavy rains, high surf, storm surges and flooding that threaten to harm communities and cause extensive damage to public and private property across the state.This emergency proclamation allows us to line up services and necessary resources prior to the event so that we can keep our communities safe and running as efficiently as possible. #HurricaneLane is not a well- behaved hurricane. I‚Äôve not seen such dramatic changes in the forecast track as I‚Äôve seen with this storm. I urge our residents and visitors to take this threat seriously and prepare for a significant impact.See proclamation here: http://bit.ly/2Mr0kZKFor more details or for a list of emergency resources click: http://bit.ly/2MFC9pD Watch video News Conference: http://bit.ly/2o0Uhw9Watch video News Conference with ASL interpreter: http://bit.ly/2OVUYCv#HiGov #HINews
description: Based on the scientific information and expertise available, Hawai‚Äòi is in danger of being significantly impacted by Hurricane Lane, whether or not the hurricane directly hits the state. The counties of Hawai‚Äòi, Maui, Kalawao, Kaua‚Äòi and the City and County of Honolulu are in danger of experiencing high winds, heavy rains, high surf, storm surges and flooding that threaten to harm communities and cause extensive damage to public and private property across the state.This emergency proclamation allows us to line up services and necessary resources prior to the event so that we can keep our communities safe and running as efficiently as possible. #HurricaneLane is not a well- behaved hurricane. I‚Äôve not seen such dramatic changes in the forecast track as I‚Äôve seen with this storm. I urge our residents and visitors to take this threat seriously and prepare for a significant impact.See proclamation here: http://bit.ly/2Mr0kZKFor more details or for a list of emergency resources click: http://bit.ly/2MFC9pD Watch video News Conference: http://bit.ly/2o0Uhw9Watch video News Conference with ASL interpreter: http://bit.ly/2OVUYCv#HiGov #HINews

author: Governor David Ige
title: Hawai ªi is bracing for the possible arrival of Hurricane Lane over the next couple days. This powerful cyclone has again strengthened to a category-4 hurricane, with maximum sustained winds of 130 mph. As of 11 a.m. today, it is 580 miles southeast of Hilo and 785 miles southeast of Honolulu, traveling in the general direction of the islands. Hurricane Lane may bring tropical-storm-force winds to parts of Hawaii as early as Wednesday morning. Even without a direct hit on our islands, tropical cyclones like Hurricane Lane can bring high winds, heavy rain, large and pounding waves, and even king tides along the coast. Major flooding and damaging surf can happen even if the eye of the storm doesn‚Äôt pass over the islands. Make sure you are prepared for Hurricane Lane and other natural disasters, with a family emergency plan and an emergency kit (with enough food, water, medication, and other essentials to last at least 14 days). To find out more information about emergency preparedness, as well as to keep up to date with Hurricane Lane, visit our Current Issues & Advisories page on Hurricane Lane: http://health.hawaii.gov/‚Ä¶/current-issues-a‚Ä¶/hurricane-lane/Stay informed with the latest news by monitoring local news broadcasts (radio, TV, or Internet) and by signing up for local emergency notification systems at the following webpages:‚Ä¢ County of Hawai ªi: countyofhawaii.bbcportal.com‚Ä¢ City & County of Honolulu: hnl.info/alerts/login.php ‚Ä¢ County of Kauai: countyofkauai.bbcportal.com‚Ä¢ County of Maui: www.co.maui.hi.us/list.aspx

author: Governor David Ige
title: ANSWER: Conditions have changed dramatically from the ‚Äô80s when sugar and pineapple were big players and I was a legislator helping to write the state‚Äôs water code. Back then, the concern was to protect plantation lands. Now we have an abundance of ag-zoned land all across the state that‚Äôs lying fallow. What we need are more people to farm and help for those who want to expand production but can‚Äôt afford to take the risk.  At our urging, the state‚Äôs Water Commission is getting stakeholders together to balance farming and housing needs instead of going to court. Also, with new, efficient greenhouse technology, the conflict between housing development and ag land preservation is no longer such a big issue.Read more of August\'s Capitol Connection newsletter: http://bit.ly/2vpi8t1Subscribe to our monthly newsletter: http://1.usa.gov/23jRyto#HIGov #HINews #CapitolConnection #SustainableHawaii

title: Hawai ªi has a bold energy agenda ‚Äì to achieve 100 percent clean energy in the electricity sector by the year 2045. To reach this goal, we need the support of everyone, including local businesses, government agencies, and non-profit organizations.    That‚Äôs why we are pleased to recognize, The Westin Nanea Ocean Villas for its energy efficiency and renewable energy achievements. We appreciate The Westin Nanea Ocean Villas bold steps to reduce, reuse and recycle; conserve Hawai ªi‚Äôs natural resources; and educate employees and customers about the importance of ‚Äúgreen‚Äù business practices. title: Awesome work. Can we work on getting more trees along the city area? We have lots of tree that could be transplanted. I notice that air is just too hot in the town area. Then when I take a drive over the Pali the air gets cooler. A little more trees to line up by free ways and even in front of some of the buildings in town will cool our community by a rapid degree percentage. From my stand point that could be our first step toward preserving our aina

author: Governor David Ige
title: Kaua ªi County, Hawaii and the City and County of Honolulu residents with losses as a result of April‚Äôs Severe Storms, Flooding, Landslides, and Mudslides have through Monday, Aug. 27, 2018 to register for disaster assistance with FEMA Federal Emergency Management Agency. Recovery officials urge residents who have yet to register to do so before the deadline.Survivors may register online at DisasterAssistance.gov or by phone at 800-621-3362 or (TTY) 800-462-7585. Applicants who use 711 or Video Relay service may call 800-621-3362. The toll-free numbers are open 8 a.m. to 6 p.m. seven days a week.Federal Disaster Assistance ASL video (Applying for FEMA disaster assistance) https://youtu.be/-xaBLlNUYM8Disaster assistance can include FEMA grants for temporary housing, home repairs and replacement, as well as low-interest disaster loans from the U.S. Small Business Administration. These loans are available to businesses, private nonprofits, homeowners and renters to cover losses not fully compensated by insurance or other recoveries. Aug. 27 is also the deadline to file a loan application for physical damages with the SBA. Applicants may apply to the SBA online at https://disasterloan.sba.gov/ela. Applicants may also call SBA‚Äôs Customer Service Center at (800) 659-2955 or email disastercustomerservice@sba.gov for more information on SBA disaster assistance. Individuals who are deaf or hard of hearing may call (800) 877-8339.üì∏Courtesy: civilbeat.org#KauaiFlooding #HIGov

author: Governor David Ige
title: The Natural Energy Laboratory of Hawaii Authority (NELHA) is set to receive a $2 million award from the U.S. Department of Energy Solar Energy Technologies Office (SETO) to advance solar-thermal desalination technologies, which can reduce cost and expand the market for creating freshwater from otherwise unusable waters.  This is another example of the exceptional value that our support and investment into the critical infrastructure of this technology park in West Hawai ªi has generated. We will continue to pursue federal funding to allow NELHA to maintain its competitive advantage and give the community an asset found in very few places in the world. This project will be the world‚Äôs largest forward osmosis (FO) solar thermal desalination plant for a high visibility ‚Äòon sun‚Äô demonstration of seawater desalination for agricultural applications.Click to learn more about this program: http://bit.ly/2K7UffLüì∏Courtesy: energy.gov#KailuaKona #HIGov #Innovation #Technology State of Hawaii Department of Business, Economic Development, and Tourism U.S. Department of Energy Office of Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy

author: Governor David Ige
title: A big mahalo and shout out to the Hawai ªi Pay Team for the successful rollout of the first and second phase of the Hawai ªi state payroll modernization project. This effort was executed by a united, highly-engaged state workforce that stepped forward to implement our vision of a modernized payroll system. This IT project has been a substantial undertaking that is on-time and on-budget. The HawaiiPay project launched in November 2016 to modernize payroll and time & attendance systems to provide greater functionality and efficiencies in serving approximately 63,000 full- and part-time employees statewide. The project represents a significant opportunity to further transform the culture of government to embrace and accelerate the adoption of more efficient, less paper-dependent ways of doing business. For more information about HIPay, visit http://bit.ly/2Pd3OwHRead about this transformation: http://bit.ly/2AJqoK0#HIGov #HINews #HIPay

author: Governor David Ige
title: The Transportation Network Companies (TNC), including Uber and Lyft, are cleared to operate at the Daniel K. Inouye International Airport (HNL) on a permanent basis. Following a series of statewide public hearings held in Honolulu, Kahului, Kona, and Lihue in late June. More than 160 individuals provided testimony on the proposed rule changes during the hearings, and an overwhelming majority of those testifiers expressed support for the changes. There will continue to be two designated areas on airport property that the TNCs will be able to pick up passengers at the Daniel K. Inouye International Airport. Both are located on the second level median curb. One pickup location is at Terminal 1 (formerly the Interisland Terminal) across from Lobby 2 and the other is located at Terminal 2 (formerly the Overseas Terminal) across from Lobby 8. Pick up locations are subject to relocation as construction at the airport proceeds. TNC permitting and pickup operations at neighbor island airports are not yet established (passenger drop-offs are already allowed). Moving forward, HDOT will review each county‚Äôs licensing regulations pertaining to the amended administrative rules for TNCs relating to neighbor island airport pickup operations.   For more information, visit: http://bit.ly/2Banj61Hawaii Department of Transportation #HIGov #HINews

author: Governor David Ige
title: ANSWER: We‚Äôve encouraged our departments to be ‚Äúsmart risk-takers‚Äù if it means delivering better results for taxpayers. In affordable housing, we revamped our processes to support public-private partnerships and made financing tools more attractive to encourage building more affordable units. We‚Äôve reduced homelessness statewide two years in a row because we changed the contracts so more service providers are working together, focusing on moving people to permanent, supportive housing instead of just filling shelter beds.  And we‚Äôre supporting game-changers like Early College and Hawai‚Äòi‚Äôs Promise to give students a head start on higher-paying jobs. Read more of August\'s Capitol Connection newsletter: http://bit.ly/2vpi8t1Subscribe to our monthly newsletter: http://1.usa.gov/23jRyto#HIGov #HINews #CapitolConnection #SustainableHawaii
description: ANSWER: We‚Äôve encouraged our departments to be ‚Äúsmart risk-takers‚Äù if it means delivering better results for taxpayers. In affordable housing, we revamped our processes to support public-private partnerships and made financing tools more attractive to encourage building more affordable units. We‚Äôve reduced homelessness statewide two years in a row because we changed the contracts so more service providers are working together, focusing on moving people to permanent, supportive housing instead of just filling shelter beds.  And we‚Äôre supporting game-changers like Early College and Hawai‚Äòi‚Äôs Promise to give students a head start on higher-paying jobs. Read more of August\'s Capitol Connection newsletter: http://bit.ly/2vpi8t1Subscribe to our monthly newsletter: http://1.usa.gov/23jRyto#HIGov #HINews #CapitolConnection #SustainableHawaii

title: ...hope you are developing greater involvement in tech school training. And sustainability can also be developed in the local farming industry. Utilize the tourism industry, but try not to make it a priority. It does not create jobs that can lift citizens out of poverty. Service oriented jobs rarely do. Tourism is a niche industry, Hawaii needs to develop products which can be exported. Items like coffee and macadamia nuts are nice, but aquaculture will draw in the world markets. It has to start somewhere. Let your administration develop the idea.

title: Unfortunately, I moved to Las Vegas before finishing my internship at Care Hawaii. I was tricked by my so-called friend who wanted me to move to Vegas with him, I went to Vegas because he needed to return to Munich for a family emergency. My friend was supposed to buy me a round trip ticket but, he didn\'t and I wound up stuck in Vegas. I was very angry because of this. Now, I am still stuck due to a stroke I had in December and I am recovering slowly. Someday I will return to Honolulu.

author: Governor David Ige
title: We held a dedication to celebrate widening of the Queen Ka ªahumanu highway. This project has been a top priority ever since we broke ground three years ago. The highway is the lifeline to some of the best Hawai ªi has to offer. I am grateful to the project team for overcoming the challenges and to Kona residents and business owners for their patience and support. Two lanes were added to the Queen Ka ªahumanu Highway between Kealakehe Parkway and Keahole Airport Road. The additional lanes were built as part of the Queen Ka ªahumanu Highway Widening Project, Phase 2, which widened approximately 5 miles of 2-lane highway and constructed a 4-lane divided highway.Mahalo to everyone for their hard work and contributions in the completion of the widening of the Queen Ka ªahumanu Highway. author: Governor David Ige
title: On June 13, 2018, Hawai‚Äòi became the first state in the nation to prohibit pesticides containing chlorpyrifos ‚Äì a chemical that has been linked to developmental delays and learning disabilities in children. Protecting the health and safety of our keiki and residents is one of my top priorities. We must protect our communities from potentially harmful chemicals. At the same time, Hawai‚Äòi‚Äôs agriculture industry is extremely important to our state and economy. We will work with the Hawaii Department of Agriculture, local farmers and the University of Hawaii at Manoa as we seek safe, alternative pest management tools that will support and sustain our agriculture industry for generations to come. #FirstInTheNation #BanChlorphyrios #HIGov #HINews Watch Senate Bill 3095 signing ceremony at http://bit.ly/2vVczTdClick to read Senate Bill 3095, now law as, Act 45: http://bit.ly/2nq5S81

author: Governor David Ige
title: Congratulations to the Hawai ªi State Commission on the Status of Women on your National Association of Commissions for Women award. Your hard work makes Hawai ªi the first state to pass Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women (CEDAW) legislation in every county.CEDAW is the only international human rights treaty that focuses entirely on ending discrimination against women. The United States is one of just six countries in the world that failed to ratify the treaty. Passage at the local level represents a proactive commitment by each county in Hawai ªi to evaluate their programs and budgets to ensure they affect men and women equitably.Khara Jabola-Carolus, Executive Director of the State Commission, stated, ‚ÄúHawai ªi is reclaiming its role in leading the nation on women‚Äôs issues. We were the first state to legalize abortion, and our late Congressperson Patsy Mink was the principle author of Title IX, which was renamed in her honor. Now, we have become the first state to codify CEDAW in every county, and to codify Title IX into state law. Despite the federal attacks, we‚Äôve made this year historic for women.‚Äù#Hawaii #FirstinTheNation #HIGov #HINews @NationalAssociationofCommissionsforWomen

author: Governor David Ige
title: Pleased to see quick action from local businesses and entrepreneurs removing coral-damaging chemicals, oxybenzone and octinoxate, from their sunscreen formulas and even more impressed by buyers who are asking for reef-safe sunscreens. I made a commitment in 2016 to protect and manage 30% of our nearshore oceans water by 2030, so signing Senate Bill 2571 was a no-brainer. Hawai ªi has started this safe reef movement and it will require all of us to inspire other states and countries to do the same. We have a responsibility to steward our natural resources, and my administration will continue to work to protect our oceans so that they can begin to heal. Will you ask for reef-safe sunscreens?Watch Senate Bill 2571 signing ceremony at http://bit.ly/2MJQZrCClick to read Senate Bill 2571, now law as, Act 107: http://bit.ly/2ARJ9v0Learn more about the Sustainable Hawai ªi Initiative: http://bit.ly/2k8ABES#Hawaii #30x30 #SafeReefMovement #SustainableHawaii #oxybenzone #octinoxateHawaii DLNR (Department of Land and Natural Resources)

title: Today the Hawai‚Äòi State Hospital in KƒÅne‚Äòohe broke ground for a new four-story, 144-bed, secure forensic psychiatric facility totaling 170,000 square feet.In 2016, the Hawai‚Äòi State Legislature supported my urgent request to address the over-crowded patient conditions and voted in favor of a major capital improvement allocation to bring Hawai‚Äòi State Hospital into the 21st century. Together, we have been able to accelerate the progress of the building without circumventing laws, taking shortcuts or compromising our integrity. title: Please do the right thing Governor and stop mainland interests from taking our sacred marine life. It\'s within your kuleana and authority to do so. Why not act in the best interests of our reefs and peoples? You were such a champion on Papahanaumokuakea and other issues. Please do what\'s pono and stop all collection at least until an EIS is conducted that also includes cultural impacts. Mahalo Governor!

title: Hawaii is home to world-renowned reefs and natural beauty. Please protect that- please protect fish populations from the aquarium trade. These reefs and wildlife additionally support Hawaii\'s economy and eco-tourism. Please do the right thing for future generations!

title: Please protect Hawaii\'s reef animals. The ocean is already being attacked at all angles from human impact. The reefs in particular need all the help they can get. They are considered the nurseries of the ocean. The short term profit of a few is not worth irrevocably damaging Hawaii\'s reef ecosystems. Please do the right thing.
description: Please protect Hawaii\'s reef animals. The ocean is already being attacked at all angles from human impact. The reefs in particular need all the help they can get. They are considered the nurseries of the ocean. The short term profit of a few is not worth irrevocably damaging Hawaii\'s reef ecosystems. Please do the right thing.

title: Why would Suzanne Case, who just a few years ago was the Hawaii head of the mainland conservation group The Nature Conservancy, think that the location of the headquarters of a non-profit dedicated to public good is relevant? In this case, she was parroting the talking points of the North American pet trade--dedicated to profit, at Hawaii\'s expense. HSUS is working with others to end the harm to Hawaii\'s marine life at the hands of the aquarium trade. You\'d think she\'d be on the side of Hawaii.

title: http://www.humanesociety.org/news/press_releases/2018/08/hawaii-governor-david-ige.html Governor David Ige Your administration has the authority to stop all collection of our coral reef wildlife for (mostly mainland) aquariums, pending an EIS...including the use of methods of take that you yourself said could be more destructive to the environment, in your defense of your veto of SB1240 last year (legislation that would have phased out the trade over a generation).  If pillaging our precious reef wildlife using fine mesh nets is in violation of HEPA in the absence of environmental review, why isn\'t all collection, regardless of method of take? Please take action - either through an immediate moratorium or rulemaking - and stop the continual flow of our natural resource out of Hawaii, until an EIS determines the environmental impact of this trade. Cathy Goeggel Ginger Towle Coy Stout Jeff Falk Doreen Virtue Jeanie Smith Kilgour Murray Kilgour Nipsy Rusel Brent Greg
description: http://www.humanesociety.org/news/press_releases/2018/08/hawaii-governor-david-ige.html Governor David Ige Your administration has the authority to stop all collection of our coral reef wildlife for (mostly mainland) aquariums, pending an EIS...including the use of methods of take that you yourself said could be more destructive to the environment, in your defense of your veto of SB1240 last year (legislation that would have phased out the trade over a generation).  If pillaging our precious reef wildlife using fine mesh nets is in violation of HEPA in the absence of environmental review, why isn\'t all collection, regardless of method of take? Please take action - either through an immediate moratorium or rulemaking - and stop the continual flow of our natural resource out of Hawaii, until an EIS determines the environmental impact of this trade. author: Governor David Ige
title: What started as an idea to tap local tech talent to improve state services has gone on to win the top State IT Innovation of the Year award from StateScoop, based in Washington, D.C. The annual award honors the nation‚Äôs most outstanding efforts to make state and local government more efficient and effective. Launched two years ago and coordinated by the Office of Enterprise Technology Services, State of Hawaii, the Hawai‚Äòi Annual Code Challenge (HACC) pairs state departments with community and student coders to develop practical computer solutions for improving services. It is a tremendous honor for the HACC to be recognized nationally and selected among the hundreds of nominations from counties and states across the nation. The HACC proves we have the talent right here in the islands to develop future tech careers. Stay tuned for your opportunity to compete in this year‚Äôs HACC which is planned for this fall. #Hawaii #HACC #CapitolConnection #HIGov #HINews

author: Governor David Ige
title: As #HurricaneHector nears, I urge you to prepare your homes and families if you have not done so. I‚Äôm working with state and federal partners to prepare even though it looks like the storm may pass to the south of the state. The U.S. National Weather Service (NWS) said as of 8:00 a.m. Tuesday, the center of Hector, which is still measuring as a Category 4 Hurricane (maximum sustained winds of 113 ‚Äì 136 mph), is 495 miles southeast of Hilo moving west at 16 mph. A Tropical Storm Watch has been issued for Hawai ªi County.Surf along east facing shores is already building and will peak later today and tonight, at 12 to 15 feet for the Big Island and 6 ‚Äì 10 feet for Maui County. Hector is expected to pass approximately 165 miles south on Wednesday.Hawaii residents and visitors are asked to take the following precautions:‚Ä¢ Continue to follow local reports for the latest information on Hector‚Ä¢ Be aware of flood safety recommendations, tips can be found at floodsmart.gov‚Ä¢ Listen to ocean safety officials and exercise caution if entering the water as high surf messages are issuedLinks to more preparation tips below:HIEMA: http://bit.ly/2OP9CMGDCCA: http://bit.ly/2ANm4d1Hawai ªi Boater‚Äôs Hurricane and Tsunami Safety Manual: http://bit.ly/2AL4shEüì∏: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) #HIGov #HINews Hawaii Emergency Management Agency Hawaii Department of Commerce and Consumer Affairs

author: Governor David Ige
title: Hawai ªi has a bold energy agenda ‚Äì to achieve 100 percent clean energy in the electricity sector by the year 2045. To reach this goal, we need the support of everyone, including local businesses, government agencies, and non-profit organizations.    That‚Äôs why we are pleased to recognize, Waialae Country Club for its energy efficiency and renewable energy achievements. We appreciate the Waialae Country Club\'s bold steps to reduce, reuse and recycle; conserve Hawai ªi‚Äôs natural resources; and educate employees and customers about the importance of ‚Äúgreen‚Äù business practices.  It is important for #Hawaii to remain a leader in clean energy and sustainability at a time when leadership in these areas at the federal level is lacking. author: Governor David Ige
title: Happy to announce the successful roll-out of the second phase of the state‚Äôs payroll modernization effort. This second phase included an additional 20,000 employees of the Legislature, Judiciary, Office of Hawaiian Affairs and Executive branch departments. The first phase covered about 1,300 employees from the Department of Accounting and General Services (DAGS) and the Department of Human Resources and Development (DHRD) and was successfully implemented in May. This IT project has been a substantial undertaking that is on-time and on-budget. This effort was successfully executed by a united, highly-engaged state workforce that stepped forward to implement our vision of a modernized payroll system. The system transforms the way the state and its employees conduct business ‚Äì creating a more efficient and effective government for state taxpayers.Read about this transformation: http://bit.ly/2AJqoK0Office of Enterprise Technology Services, State of Hawaii #HIGov #HINews #HIPayroll

author: Governor David Ige
title: Update: Hurricane Hector expected to produce high surf on state\'s east-facing shores. The National Weather Service (NWS) briefed Hawaii Emergency Management Agency (HI-EMA), local emergency management and Hawaii County Civil Defense Agency, and federal and state partners this morning about Hurricane Hector, which has reached Category 4 strength. The center of the system is currently located approximately 850 miles east-southeast of Hilo and moving west at 15 mph. Forecasters expect Hector to move west-northwest for the next two days. However, the exact timing of the anticipated turn is somewhat uncertain at this stage.High surf is expected to impact east-facing shores of Hawaii Island and East Maui, with heights building today through Tuesday and peaking Tuesday night/Wednesday. Surf may reach 15 to 20 feet. HI-EMA and its partners continue to closely monitor the storm, and recommend the following precautions to the public as Hurricane Hector remains in the Central Pacific:‚Ä¢ Listen to ocean safety officials and exercise caution if entering the water as high surf messages are issued.‚Ä¢ Read the Hawaii Boater‚Äôs Hurricane and Tsunami Safety Manual for recommended precautions to protect your boat prior to a storm at http://bit.ly/2AL4shE#HIGov #HInews #HurricaneHector

author: Governor David Ige
title: ANSWER: Yes, for me sustaining Hawai‚Äòi is part of a bigger mission of changing our economy so we can be more self-reliant. Instead of sending billions of dollars out of state for fuel or food, we need to generate more of our own energy and increase local food production. Then we could keep that money in our economy and have more capital for education, business development and job creation. I do think people are connecting the dots to see that protecting the environment, expanding clean energy,  increasing food production and supporting innovation in every sector helps us all. Read more of August\'s Capitol Connection newsletter at http://bit.ly/2vpi8t1Subscribe to our monthly newsletter at http://1.usa.gov/23jRyto#HIGov #HINews #CapitolConnection #SustainableHawaii

title: You are forgetting 1 of Hawaii\'s dirty little secret. Millions of tons of single use plastic! Every single day plastic is allowed to be sold then used only once by millions of people each day. Millions of plastic straws, lids, cups, bottles, over and over and over. A total disgrace for one of the most beautiful and fragile places on earth! #SingleUsePlastic is choking our Ocean and harming our #Ania yet #Hawaii still produces tons of 1 time use plastic every single day! Yes there is a storm coming, a potential natural disaster. But a forever storm of Plastic keeps growing! Who is doing anything about it? It\'s all about convience and $$$. And it\'s piling up on our land and into our sea. The truth is there are alternatives to plastic, but they are being ignored! The question is WHY? Who\'s getting paid, while the plastic waste piles up?

title: Hawai ªi has a bold energy agenda ‚Äì to achieve 100 percent clean energy in the electricity sector by the year 2045. To reach this goal, we need the support of everyone, including local businesses, government agencies, and non-profit organizations.    That‚Äôs why we are pleased to recognize, Sony Open in Hawaii for its energy efficiency and renewable energy achievements. We appreciate the Sony Open\'s bold steps to reduce, reuse and recycle; conserve Hawai ªi‚Äôs natural resources; and educate employees and customers about the importance of ‚Äúgreen‚Äù business practices.  It is important for #Hawaii to remain a leader in clean energy and sustainability at a time when leadership in these areas at the federal level is lacking. title: The lava flows and volcanic activity continue to endanger communities in the Puna District, and are expected to continue causing additional losses, suffering, and the displacement of individuals and families. I signed a third supplementary proclamation to extend emergency assistance as volcanic eruption continues on Hawai‚Äòi Island. This supplementary proclamation extends the authority to spend state funds as appropriated for quick and efficient action to protect the health, safety and welfare of our Hawai‚Äòi County residents. This also helps to provide quick relief of suffering, damage, and losses caused by the eruption.The initial emergency proclamation was signed on May 3, the day the latest eruption began. I issued the first supplementary proclamation on May 9, and the second supplementary proclamation on June 5. The third supplementary proclamation issued today is effective until Oct. 2, 2018.Supplementary Proclamation: http://bit.ly/2nbrPri #KilaueaEruption #LeilaniEstates #HIGov #HINews

title: Pleased to announce that beginning September 1st we will begin a year-long trial of testing alternative fuel technologies to power shuttle buses between airport terminals and the temporary consolidated rent-a-car facility. Hawai ªi is committed to making a clean energy transformation. As an island state at risk of rising sea levels and climate change, we can‚Äôt afford not to be. While the federal government is attempting to roll back emissions standards, we are proud to surge ahead with the largest renewable airport bus fleet program in the nation. I am committed to reaching our goal of 100% clean energy by 2045.The pilot program adds to energy savings initiatives at state airports such as the replacement of over 98,000 lighting fixtures at airports statewide and the installation of 4,260 solar modules on the roof of HNL‚Äôs Terminal 1 parking structure.Mahalo to all of our partners: Hawaii Gas, Hawaiian Electric Companies, Roberts Hawaii, Ricando, and the rental car companies.Continue reading: http://bit.ly/2naETx9Photos: http://bit.ly/2n9GUtaClick to learn more about the Sustainable Hawaii Initiative: http://bit.ly/2k8ABES #100by2045 #CleanEnergy #WeAre100 #HIGov #HINews Hawaii Department of Transportation

author: Governor David Ige
title: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) estimates that 48 million Americans get sick from a foodborne illness each year, 128,000 are hospitalized, and 3,000 die. I am grateful to receive funding to help Hawai ªi food producers comply with the Food Safety Modernization Act and Rule so that we can keep our community healthy and safe. This newly funded program will be especially helpful to Hawai ªi‚Äôs smaller farms over the next three years. It will provide guidance and technical assistance so they may comply with the new federal food safety regulations. Supporting farmers in this way will strengthen our food systems and help attain our goal of doubling Hawai ªi‚Äôs food production by 2020. Read more at http://bit.ly/2OG6L8WLearn about my initiative to double food production by 2020 by visiting http://bit.ly/2BPWAXD#HIGov #HINews Hawaii Department of Agriculture

title: Good to hear Governor David Ige!  One of the greatest ways insure food safety is implemented; I would suggest a Large Packing Shed with USDA Inspectors.  As a young teenager I grew up and worked on large and small farms.  California Farmers have always had USDA at packing sheds to engage with Farmers, and labor to ensure the best produce reaches home across the planet.  Farm Fresh starts with the pickers and tractor drivers delivering to sheds and cold storages.  The faster your produce is delivered to packing shed the less likely to collect harmful bacteria. Packing sheds are designed to kill any harmful bacteria from sitting in the fields.  The care that is taken in the Produce once picked is vital to food safety.  One thing to remember is that Hawaii produce tends to go stale quicker do to the lack of packing sheds and cold storages.  The reason is simple.  Produce that is just picked should leave for treatment and packing followed by cold storage within a couple hours.

title: Until we start to crack down on feral cats (transmiting disease to our endangered monk seals), rats and mongoose, pigs and axis deer, we don\'t have a chance. Little Fire Ants, Rat Lung worm, Cat scratch fever, Coffee Berry Borer, Ambrosia beetles spreading Rapid Ohia Death.....Our humane society actually traped feral cats at our waterfront Lili\'uokalani Gardens Park, had them fixed and then returned them! People feed them, which also feeds the little fire ants, rats and mongoose, which in turn helps to spread Rat lung worm and Cat Scratch fever to the visiting dogs and possibly even to people useing the gardens as well as endangering the volunteres and public workers that work in the parks. How much money are we throwing at the problem and not educating people why these feral cats should be distroyed? People here don\'t even want to kill rats and mongoose and cane toads(which also all kill and eat ground nesting bird eggs)!  Good luck

title: Governor Ige - thank you - I had the pleasure and honor of meeting with Chief of Staff , Mr . McCartney, last year on the issue of homeless cats .  To sum up, cats are domestic animals and not wildlife .  homelessness for Cats created by humans , to be solved humanely by humans .  DLNR oversees and manages wildlife, and they are unable to have adequate representation and reasonable understanding or motives , in solely ‚Äòlabeling ‚Äò or maintaining or even determining policy re homeless domestic animals.  I‚Äôve also spoken with Chief Vet at NOAA who confirms and echos this - cats are not classified as wildlife .  I‚Äôve also spoken with the epidemiology dept of DOH , and went over the stats - there is no escalation of concern.  From a sociological perspective : To destroy them is to encourage sociopathic tendencies in the public.  It runs counter to humane ideas and laws.  It will be a multi-factorial humane cooperative approach that comes from humans , many groups not just Dlnr , to address, contain and solve the issues .  I hope to always be part of a sane and humane solution .  Like most solutions , they are thought out and have more complexity than a quick short sighted response .  A recent balanced article is in the Star Advertiser supported by the mayor , and Trevor Ozawa , was so pleased to see .  Mahalo

author: Governor David Ige
title: A VISION FOR A 21st CENTURY FUTURE: The name sounds like child‚Äôs play, but the vision is real: Creating workspaces such as the Entrepreneur‚Äôs Sandbox in Kaka‚Äòako that support technology and innovation ‚Äî the foundation for the my administration‚Äôs goal of creating 80,000 new jobs paying $80,000 a year by 2030. An April groundbreaking ceremony for the $7.3 million project marked the start of the Kaka‚Äòako Innovation Block and tech park, just ewa of the John A. Burns School of Medicine. The project is planned as a business incubator space and will be operated by the Hawaii Technology Development Corporation - HTDC.I praised the project as a true public-private partnership with the Department of Business Economic Development and Tourism, the Hawai‚Äòi Community Development Authority, the U.S. Department of Commerce Economic Development Administration, the Legislature and developer Stanford Carr.This level of collaboration is the only way we will successfully take the state where we need to go: delivering new products and services to the global marketplace, creating good jobs, and providing a sustainable economy. Read more in July\'s Capitol Connection newsletter at http://bit.ly/2KGRYLMSubscribe to our monthly newsletter at http://1.usa.gov/23jRyto#HIGov #HINews #CapitolConnection #technology #innovationState of Hawaii Department of Business, Economic Development, and Tourism

author: Governor David Ige
title: #TemporaryMicroHousing: From temporary shelters to FEMA relief centers, farm loans and state and federal aid of all types ‚Äî the message to disaster survivors on three islands is clear: You‚Äôre not alone. The federal government, a multitude of state and county agencies and I have mobilized efforts to offer support ‚Äî on the ground and in person as thousands of residents try to rebuild their lives after devastating floods and the on-going Kƒ´lauea eruption.Since the April floods on Kaua‚Äòi and O‚Äòahu and the continuing volcanic activity on Hawai‚Äòi island, I have criss-crossed the state to assess the damage and ensure residents get the help they need. Here‚Äôs the latest news on disaster relief from FEMA:Hawaii Army National Guard soldiers and community volunteers are working together to build an emergency community of temporary micro-housing units for seniors over age 60 and families with children under 18 left homeless by the lava flow. It‚Äôs hoped the ‚Äúvillage‚Äù on the grounds of Sacred Heart Church in Pahoa could be the first of others from faith-based groups who want to help people who have been living in shelters after losing their homes to the eruption.                                                                  Read more in July\'s Capitol Connection newsletter at http://bit.ly/2KGRYLMSubscribe to our monthly newsletter at http://1.usa.gov/23jRyto#HIGov #HINews #KilaueaVolcano #KilaueaEruption #CapitolConnection

author: Governor David Ige
title: Keahumoa Place in East Kapolei is exactly the kind of housing projects we need in Hawai ªi. The multi-family housing apartment community will provide Hawai ªi families with 320 new, affordable rental units by 2020 and will remain affordable for 65 years. Keahumoa Place is a prime example of how my administration has attracted more private investment in Hawai ªi by engaging with companies such as The Michaels Organization, to construct more affordable housing for our residents. There is no better place for this new affordable rental community than on previously vacant state within close-proximity to rail stations, public transportation and employment centers.Mahalo to all the partners who made this a reality.üì∏: Kent Miyasaki #HIGov #AffordableHousing #10Kby2020

author: Governor David Ige
title: I am proud to join my fellow governors, Hawai‚Äòi residents, and millions of Americans in opposing the proposed gag rule on Title X. This is not an issue about life or choices. This is an issue about the rights of millions of individuals who deserve the best health care available. Legally and ethically, patients have the right to learn about all their medical options and determine for themselves which option is best. The gag rule undermines that right and puts women‚Äôs health in grave danger.The governors are threatening to withdraw from the Title X program should the proposed rule be finalized and enacted. The State of Hawai‚Äòi will explore all options available to ensure that the proposed rules do not threaten the health and wellbeing of our women, and the integrity of the state‚Äôs family planning program. Hawai‚Äòi will not accept federal funds for these programs if the proposed rules are implemented.Continue reading at http://bit.ly/2LPHvOD#HIGov #HINews #SaveTitleX #NoGagRule #ProtectLife

title: That‚Äôs according to the latest edition of Morning Consult‚Äôs Governor Approval Rankings, compiled from online surveys conducted with almost 275,000 registered voters from Jan. 1 through March 31. See our methodology here.The top four in the rankings remain unchanged from the fourth quarter of 2017, with Govs. Charlie Baker of Massachusetts, Larry Hogan of Maryland, Kay Ivey of Alabama and Phil Scott of Vermont enjoying support from at least 65 percent of their constituents. New Hampshire‚Äôs Chris Sununu and North Dakota‚Äôs Doug Burgum rejoin the top 10 in lieu of Asa Hutchinson of Arkansas and Greg Abbott of Texas.At the other end of the table, Gov. Dan Malloy (D-Conn.) is now the most unpopular governor, replacing former Republican Govs. Chris Christie of New Jersey and Sam Brownback of Kansas, who traded the dubious distinction during the past two years. Malloy isn‚Äôt seeking a third term in office, but five governors in the bottom 10 are on the ballot in 2018: Bruce Rauner (R-Ill.),  Bill Walker (I-Alaska), Gina Raimondo (D-R.I.), Scott Walker (R-Wis.) and David Ige (D-Hawaii).

author: Governor David Ige
title: We‚Äôre moving toward more efficient and open state government. The Hawai ªi\'s state government goes through about 12 million pages of paper a year and this new pilot program has reduced 20% of paper usage by transitioning from printed documents to electronic reports. In just three years, for example, the state is projected to save $500,000 and 10 million sheets of printed paper, benefiting both the environment and tax payers dollars.Transforming from a paper-dependent culture to a digital environment improves public accessibility to government documents and increases transparency for our citizens. Electronic documents make it easier to store and retrieve documents. More details via Hawaii News Now: http://bit.ly/2LAtbudüì∏ Office of Enterprise Technology Services, State of Hawaii

title: That\'s great. The WIC program continues to waste paper, ink, and electric by staying on the antiquated check program. 10 years behind most states who use a card, much like the EBT card. I\'ve lived here 6 years and every year when I ask I\'m told "next year".  Can we please move a little faster on that? It would also save time for families and cashier alike, as a card will allow for 1 transaction for all WIC items as opposed to separate ones for each checks. No duplicate receipts, no signatures, just swipe a card. It would save the state lots of money.

author: Governor David Ige
title: #HurricanLane update as of 11:13AM: No changes to watches and warnings. Hurricane Lane remains a major category 4 storm late this morning, with maximum sustained winds of 130 mph. As of 11 AM HST, Hurricane Lane was located around 200 miles south-southwest of Kailua-Kona, Hawaii and 275 miles south of Honolulu, Hawaii. Lane is moving toward the northwest at around 7 mph. A slow northward motion is expected to begin this afternoon and continue through Friday. A turn toward thewest is expected Saturday and Sunday, with an increase in forward speed. The latest forecast track from the Central Pacific Hurricane Center brings the center of Lane dangerously close to the main Hawaiian Islands Thursday afternoon through Saturday. Regardless of the exact track, life threatening impacts are likely over many areas as this strong hurricane makes its closest approach. Do not focus onthe exact forecast track or intensity of Lane. Be prepared for changes in future forecasts. Although the official forecast does not explicitly indicate Lane`s center making landfall over any of the islands, this could still occur.Continue reading here http://bit.ly/2MOWmcE Track Lane at http://www.prh.noaa.gov/hnl/#HIGov #HINews

author: Governor David Ige
title: 5pm: #HurricaneLane remains a dangerous category 3 storm as it slowly moves NNW. A Tropical Storm Warning has replaced the Hurricane Warning for Hawaii Island, but flooding is still a major concern. The highest threat of rain/wind shifts to Maui overnight and to Oahu through Friday. Track lane at http://www.prh.noaa.gov/hnl/ #hiwxFollow me on Twitter at https://twitter.com/GovHawaii to get statewide updates on #Lane.* WIND    - LATEST LOCAL FORECAST: Equivalent Tropical Storm force wind        - Peak Wind Forecast: 35-45 mph with gusts to 65 mph        - Window for Tropical Storm force winds: early Friday morning          until early Saturday morning    - POTENTIAL THREAT TO LIFE AND PROPERTY: Potential for wind 58 to      73 mph        - The wind threat has remained nearly steady from the          previous assessment.        - PLAN: Plan for dangerous wind of equivalent strong tropical          storm force due to possible forecast changes in track,          size, or intensity.        - PREPARE: Remaining efforts to protect life and property          should be completed as soon as possible. Prepare for          significant wind damage.        - ACT: Move to safe shelter before the wind becomes hazardous.    - POTENTIAL IMPACTS: Significant        - Some damage to roofing and siding materials, along with          damage to porches, awnings, carports, and sheds. A few          buildings experiencing window, door, and garage door          failures. Mobile homes damaged, especially if unanchored.          Unsecured lightweight objects become dangerous projectiles.        - Several large trees snapped or uprooted, but with greater          numbers in places where trees are shallow rooted. Several          fences and roadway signs blown over.        - Some roads impassable from large debris, and more within          urban or heavily wooded places. A few bridges, causeways,          and access routes impassable.        - Scattered power and communications outages, but more          prevalent in areas with above ground lines.* STORM SURGE    - No storm surge inundation forecast    - POTENTIAL THREAT TO LIFE AND PROPERTY: Little to no storm surge      flooding        - The storm surge threat has remained nearly steady from the          previous assessment.        - PLAN: There is little to no threat of storm surge flooding.          Rough surf, coastal erosion, and life-threatening rip          currents are possible.        - PREPARE: Little to no preparations for storm surge flooding          are needed.        - ACT: Follow the instructions of local officials. Monitor          forecasts.    - POTENTIAL IMPACTS: Little to None        - Little to no potential impacts from storm surge flooding.* FLOODING RAIN    - LATEST LOCAL FORECAST: Flash Flood Watch is in effect        - Peak Rainfall Amounts: 3-6 inches, with locally higher          amounts    - POTENTIAL THREAT TO LIFE AND PROPERTY: Potential for extreme      flooding rain        - The flooding rain threat has remained nearly steady from          the previous assessment.        - PLAN: Emergency plans should include the potential for          extreme flooding from heavy rain. Evacuations and rescues          are likely.        - PREPARE: Urgently consider protective actions from extreme          and widespread rainfall flooding.        - ACT: Heed any flood watches and warnings. Failure to take          action will likely result in serious injury or loss of life.    - POTENTIAL IMPACTS: Devastating to Catastrophic        - Extreme rainfall flooding may prompt numerous evacuations          and rescues.        - Rivers and tributaries may overwhelmingly overflow their          banks in many places with deep moving water. Small streams,          creeks, canals, arroyos, and ditches may become raging          rivers. In mountain areas, deadly runoff may rage down          valleys while increasing susceptibility to rockslides and          mudslides. Flood control systems and barriers may become          stressed.        - Flood waters can enter numerous structures within multiple          communities, some structures becoming uninhabitable or          washed away. Numerous places where flood waters may cover          escape routes. Streets and parking lots become rivers of          raging water with underpasses submerged. Driving conditions          become very dangerous. Numerous road and bridge closures          with some weakened or washed out.* TORNADO    - LATEST LOCAL FORECAST:        - Situation is somewhat favorable for tornadoes    - POTENTIAL THREAT TO LIFE AND PROPERTY: Potential for a few      tornadoes        - The tornado threat has remained nearly steady from the          previous assessment.        - PLAN: Emergency plans should include the potential for a          few tornadoes.        - PREPARE: If your shelter is particularly vulnerable to          tornadoes, prepare to relocate to safe shelter before          hazardous weather arrives.        - ACT: If a tornado warning is issued, be ready to shelter          quickly.    - POTENTIAL IMPACTS: Limited        - The occurrence of isolated tornadoes can hinder the          execution of emergency plans during tropical events.        - A few places may experience tornado damage, along with          power and communications disruptions.        - Locations could realize roofs peeled off buildings,          chimneys toppled, mobile homes pushed off foundations or          overturned, large tree tops and branches snapped off,          shallow-rooted trees knocked over, moving vehicles blown          off roads, and small boats pulled from moorings.Stay safe. Be vigilant.

Numerous places where flood waters may cover          escape routes. Streets and parking lots become rivers of          raging water with underpasses submerged. Driving conditions          become very dangerous. Numerous road and bridge closures          with some weakened or washed out.* TORNADO    - LATEST LOCAL FORECAST:        - Situation is somewhat favorable for tornadoes    - POTENTIAL THREAT TO LIFE AND PROPERTY: Potential for a few      tornadoes        - The tornado threat has remained nearly steady from the          previous assessment.        - PLAN: Emergency plans should include the potential for a          few tornadoes.        - PREPARE: If your shelter is particularly vulnerable to          tornadoes, prepare to relocate to safe shelter before          hazardous weather arrives.        - ACT: If a tornado warning is issued, be ready to shelter          quickly.    - POTENTIAL IMPACTS: Limited        - The occurrence of isolated tornadoes can hinder the          execution of emergency plans during tropical events.        - A few places may experience tornado damage, along with          power and communications disruptions.        - Locations could realize roofs peeled off buildings,          chimneys toppled, mobile homes pushed off foundations or          overturned, large tree tops and branches snapped off,          shallow-rooted trees knocked over, moving vehicles blown          off roads, and small boats pulled from moorings.Stay safe. Be vigilant.

Thank youRick

author: Governor David Ige
title: Flight cancellations announced earlier today have resulted in travelers going to airports statewide to depart Hawai‚Äòi earlier than scheduled without having a confirmed ticket..The Hawai‚Äòi State Department of Transportation (DOT) and Hawai‚Äòi Tourism Authority (HTA) are advising travelers to have confirmed tickets for flights scheduled that day before going to the airport. Customers wanting to make adjustments to their travel schedule should call their respective airlines to rebook flights first, then proceed to the airport..For example, Kahului Airport (OGG) is currently assisting roughly 60 travelers who came to the airport seeking to leave the island ahead of their regularly scheduled departures. Unfortunately, with changes to the schedule of outgoing flights, those passengers will likely have to shelter in place at the airport overnight unless they can secure temporary lodging accommodations..Travelers whose flights have been cancelled and have not checked out of their accommodations, should continue to shelter in place, if possible, or consider seeking safety at the nearest emergency shelter..News release available for download:https://www.hawaiitourismauthority.org/news/news-releases/.HURRICANE LANE UPDATES:https://www.hawaiitourismauthority.org/‚Ä¶/hurricane-lane-up‚Ä¶/.#HawaiiHTA #HurricaneLane

author: Governor David Ige
title: 11pm: #HurricaneLane remains a dangerous category 3 storm as it slowly moves NNW. #Lane is about 165 MI SW of Kailua-Kona and 215 MI S of Honolulu. Maximum sustained winds of 120 MPH moving at 6 MPH. A Hurricane Warning is in effect for Oahu, Maui County including the islands of Maui, Lanai, Molokai andKahoolawe. A Tropical Storm Warning is in effect for Hawaii County A Hurricane Watch is in effect for Kauai County...including the islands of Kauai and NiihauMaximum sustained winds are near 120 mph with highergusts. Lane remains a powerful category 3 hurricane with some weakening is forecast from Friday through late Saturday, but Lane is expected to remain ahurricane as it approaches the islands. Hurricane-force winds extend outward up to 35 miles from the center and tropical-storm-force winds extend outward up to 125 miles WIND: Tropical storm conditions are already occurring on the Big Island, Maui County and Oahu. These conditions will likely persist through early Friday morning. Hurricane conditions are expected over some areas of Maui County and Oahu starting Friday and continuing through Friday night. Tropical storm or hurricane conditions are possible on Kauai starting late Friday or Friday night. RAINFALL: Rain bands will continue to overspread the Hawaiian Islands well ahead of Lane. Excessive rainfall associated with this slow moving hurricane will continue to impact the Hawaiian Islands into the weekend, leading to significant and life-threatening flash flooding and landslides. Lane is expected to produce total rainaccumulations of 10 to 20 inches, with localized amounts of 30 to 40 inches possible over portions of the Hawaiian Islands. Over two feet of rain has already fallen at a few locations on the windward side of the Big Island. SURF: Very large swells generated by the slow moving hurricane will severely impact the Hawaiian Islands over the next couple of days. These swells will produce extremely large and damaging surf along exposed west and south facing shorelines. A prolonged period of highsurf will likely lead to significant coastal erosion. STORM SURGE: The combination of a dangerous storm surge and large breaking waves will raise water levels by as much as 2 to 4 feet above normal tide levels along south and west facing shores near the center of Lane. The surge will be accompanied by large anddestructive waves.Continue tracking lane at http://www.prh.noaa.gov/hnl/ #hiwx #HIGov #HInews

author: Governor David Ige
title: #HurricaneLane: Announcing the formation of a Dual-Status Command, Joint Task Force 50 (JTF) in response to Hurricane Lane\'s impact on the state of Hawai ªi. The  formal request to appoint Brig. Gen. Kenneth Hara was submitted on Thursday, Aug. 23, 2018 and approved by Secretary of Defense James N. Mattis earlier today.Our federal partners have been quick to respond to our requests for assistance in the face of Hurricane Lane, and I thank Secretary Mattis for his speedy approval. This joint military task force will provide the necessary state and federal resources to any county in Hawai ªi that needs assistance. Together, we are committed to supporting the residents of Hawai ªi in their time of need.The formation of JTF-50 establishes a clear chain of command to maintain operational unity between state and federal efforts and increase efficiency. For example, Gen. Hara now has the authority to command both the National Guard and active military forces to plan for and be ready to execute those plans should vital roadways be blocked with debris or if a mass air evacuations are necessary.Approval letter for designation of Dual-Status Commander:http://bit.ly/2Ltv9I4More: http://bit.ly/2LpL9dUHara is the Deputy Adjutant General and Commander of the Hawai ªi Army National Guard. He will oversee a joint Hawai ªi National Guard and active duty military joint task force. Based on the current threat JTF-50 may be required for Search and Rescue, Incident Awareness and Assessment, Debris Clearance, Security, and Emergency Evacuation.

author: Governor David Ige
title: #HurricaneLane NEWS CONFERENCE on formation of Dual-Status Command.This joint military task force will provide the necessary state and federal resources to any county in Hawai ªi that needs assistance. Together, we are committed to supporting the residents of Hawai ªi in their time of need.The formation of JTF-50 establishes a clear chain of command to maintain operational unity between state and federal efforts and increase efficiency. Gen. Hara now has the authority to command both the National Guard and active military forces to plan for and be ready to execute those plans should vital roadways be blocked with debris or if a mass air evacuations are necessary. Hara is the Deputy Adjutant General and Commander of the Hawai ªi Army National Guard. He will oversee a joint Hawai ªi National Guard and active duty military joint task force. Based on the current threat JTF-50 may be required for Search and Rescue, Incident Awareness and Assessment, Debris Clearance, Security, and Emergency Evacuation.Background information about the Dual Status Commander authority The Dual Status Commander is a legally authorized military officer who assumes simultaneous but mutually exclusive command authority over both National Guard forces and Title 10 federal military forces. While state and federal military forces maintain separate and distinct chains of command, the Dual Status Commander leads all military forces and directs their response efforts.
description: #HurricaneLane NEWS CONFERENCE on formation of Dual-Status Command.This joint military task force will provide the necessary state and federal resources to any county in Hawai ªi that needs assistance. Together, we are committed to supporting the residents of Hawai ªi in their time of need.The formation of JTF-50 establishes a clear chain of command to maintain operational unity between state and federal efforts and increase efficiency. Gen. Hara now has the authority to command both the National Guard and active military forces to plan for and be ready to execute those plans should vital roadways be blocked with debris or if a mass air evacuations are necessary. Hara is the Deputy Adjutant General and Commander of the Hawai ªi Army National Guard. He will oversee a joint Hawai ªi National Guard and active duty military joint task force. Based on the current threat JTF-50 may be required for Search and Rescue, Incident Awareness and Assessment, Debris Clearance, Security, and Emergency Evacuation.Background information about the Dual Status Commander authority The Dual Status Commander is a legally authorized military officer who assumes simultaneous but mutually exclusive command authority over both National Guard forces and Title 10 federal military forces. While state and federal military forces maintain separate and distinct chains of command, the Dual Status Commander leads all military forces and directs their response efforts.

author: Governor David Ige
title: 5pm: #Lane has weakened considerably through the day today thanks to strong shear near the islands. Lane is now a Tropical Storm with max winds of 70 mph and still poses a threat for flooding through tomorrow. A Tropical Storm Warning has replaced all Hurricane Warnings. ‚Ä™Lane is 160 miles west of Kailua-Kona, Hawaii, and is moving to the northwest at 3 mph.‚Ä¨‚Ä™This northwestward motion is expected through tonight, followed by a westward course Saturday with increasing forward speed. This path will take Lane away from the islands. Regardless of the storm\'s track, life threatening impacts extends far beyond the center\'s location. Do not focus on the exact forecast track or intensity of Lane. ‚Ä¨‚Ä™Tropical storm conditions are already occurring in Maui County and will continue through tonight. ‚Ä¨‚Ä™A slow moving rain band associated with Hurricane Lane continues to affect the island chain this evening. There is the possibility the band will linger over the islands through tonight. Heavy rains and flash flooding are still ongoing especially over windward Haleakala on Maui. Showers have recently been increasing across Molokai. The potential for excessive rainfall remains is high, which could lead to life threatening flash flooding, as well as land and mudslides. Flooding will be possible in areas that are typically not prone to flooding. Although Lane is weakening, it still has the potential to produce rain accumulations of 10 to 20 inches, with localized higher amounts. ‚Ä¨‚Ä™Swells generated by Lane will produce large and life-threatening surf and dangerous rip currents along shores with a southern exposure. A prolonged period of high surf will likely lead to significant coastal erosion. ‚Ä¨‚Ä™A High Surf Advisory is in effect for the south facing shores of the smaller islands through tonight at 8 to 12 feet. A High Surf Advisory remains in effect for the east facing shores of all islands at 10 to 14 feet through Saturday.‚Ä¨‚Ä™The combination of storm surge and large breaking waves is expected to raise water levels above normal tide levels. This is expected to result in beach erosion and overwash onto vulnerable coastal roadways through Saturday, particularly for vulnerable low-lying coastal areas during and around the time of normal high tide cycles. ‚Ä¨‚Ä™Tornadoes and large waterspouts are still possible with Lane, mainly along and to the right of the track of Lane. ‚Ä¨‚Ä™INFORMATION: Maui County Emergency Management Agency will continue to monitor the situation. Please listen to your local radio and TV stations or NOAA Weather Radio for any updates. NOAA Weather broadcasts can be reached by calling 1-866-944-5025. NOAA Weather internet services can be found at weather.gov/hawaii. ‚Ä¨

author: Governor David Ige
title: West Maui residents and businesses are strongly urged to conserve water tonight and into tomorrow (Saturday). The Department of Water Supply is unable to operate its pumps due to the power outage, and the surface water treatment facilities cannot process the muddy water inflow.After power is restored, it will take some time to restore tank levels; therefore, customers should use water for health and safety purposes only until Sunday.Customers are asked to check www.mauicounty.gov for updates and only call the 24/7 service line in case of water emergency.

author: Governor David Ige
title: Hawai ªi has a bold energy agenda ‚Äì to achieve 100 percent clean energy in the electricity sector by the year 2045. To reach this goal, we need the support of everyone, including local businesses, government agencies, and non-profit organizations.    That‚Äôs why we are pleased to recognize, The Kahala Hotel & Resort for its energy efficiency and renewable energy achievements. We appreciate The Kahala Hotel & Resort\'s  bold steps to reduce, reuse and recycle; conserve Hawai ªi‚Äôs natural resources; and educate employees and customers about the importance of ‚Äúgreen‚Äù business practices.  It is important for #Hawaii to remain a leader in clean energy and sustainability at a time when leadership in these areas at the federal level is lacking. Mahalo and Congratulations. #HIGov #HINews #RenewableEnergy State of Hawaii Department of Business, Economic Development, and TourismTo learn more about Hawaii Sustainable Initiative click: http://bit.ly/2k8ABES
