title: McCain\'s real legacy is: His father was the Admiral in charge of the Pacific fleet prosecuting the war in Vietnam.Because of this McCain got preferential treatment in the Navy. He was allowed to become a Navy pilot. But he was a terrible pilot.McCain crashed two navy Jets in his early career. Then while aboard the Aircraft Carrier USS Forrestal, McCain got angry because he had to wait in line to take off on a bombing run.He shut off his engines, opened the cockpit, and in his haste to exit the aircraft to chew someone out about his having to " wait", he hit the button that released his live bombs onto the deck of the Forrestal.He took off running, as the bombs exploded, which set off a chain reaction of bombs from adjacent aircraft, and the ensuing explosions and fires killed 133 sailors aboard the Forrestal.While his fellow sailors were fighting the fire, McCain went to the pilot\'s lounge below decks and watched the men fight the fire on closed circuit TV.Hours later, McCain took off with a New York Times reporter buddy of his, and went on to say that after seeing the effects of those bombs on the Forrestal, he was beginning to question the morality of dropping those bombs on the Viet Cong.McCain was the direct cause of 133 deaths on his own ship, and was never reprimanded. He was nowhere to be found as the Forrestal had to limp to the Philippines for months of repair work.McCain was married then. His wife was stricken with debilitating injuries in an automobile accident. And was hospitalized for more than 5 months. McCain was off gallivanting with anything in a skirt.Upon returning from Vietnam Nam, McCain found his wife was disfigured by her injuries, which included a shattered pelvis, arm, and legs. In order to save her legs, doctors performed 23 surgeries on her, and had to remove significant portions of the bones in her legs, which left he shorter, and unable to walk, and in a wheelchair, she had to use a catheter.McCain was disinterested in his first wife\'s predicament. She had to go through grueling physical therapy to learn to walk again.After McCain left the Navy, he was intent on a career in politics. He and His wife Carol had gotten to know Ronald and Nancy Reagan, and McCain was eager to jump into politics.But he decided he needed a more visually pleasing young woman by his side. He callously divorced Carol, the mother of his three children, and immediately jumped into the sack with new wife Cindy, who was 18 years younger.Upon learning of this, the Reagans were shocked and angered by how he had treated Carol.While campaigning for congress, McCain used pictures of himself posing with Mr. And Mrs. Reagan, but there was no hearty endorsement offered by the Reagans.McCain\'s new young wife was also an heiress to an Arizona Brewing fortune.And let us not forget McCain was one of the Keating 5, who had helped swindle life savings from countless Americans in the Savings and Loan scandal of the 1980\'s. McCain was in it up to his eyeballs.Yet McCain was well-connected in Washington, and parlayed his connections into a seat in the United States Senate.So before the tearful tributes to John McCain, be sure you remember the facts about this self-proclaimed Maverick. The facts do not agree with that portrait of a heroic patriot and great American.With due respect to his family, John McCain was never the great man so many portray him as.I do not wish the man any harm or ill-will. But neither should we allow this false narrative fairy-tale about this scoundrel of a man as he faces his eternal fate. can see what John McCain really is

title: Aloha Governor! I hope you noticed how Mauna Kea truly played a HUGE role in shearing away Hurricane lane and quickly reducing it to a tropical storm. The satellite images look as if the mauna took a literal bite out of the storm.Please.....consider this about the future of the TMT and how Native Hawaiians feel about this family member that has protected them for more than a thousand years.While it is only a resource to the state, it is like driving the nails into the hands of Jesus Christ to Christians to see Mauna Kea so treated.Please...consider, not just the sacredness...but the true topographical nature of the protection this mountain provides for the entire archipelago.I truly do not see you as a Pontius Pilate but do see you as a progressive leader in our Democratic Party. Please...Governor, "Help protect Mauna kea for the present and future generations"!

author: Governor David Ige
title: I attended a deployment ceremony today for soldiers from Alpha and Bravo Troops, 1st Squadron, 299th Cavalry Regiment, and elements of the 29th Infantry Brigade Combat Team, both from the Hawaii Army National Guard.As a father and husband, it is with much gratitude that I acknowledge your service to make the world a better place, a safer place for all families, here and abroad ‚Äì and especially in Egypt and Kosovo.I pledged that the state will provide local resources to the families of the soldiers serving on deployment.  The 1-299th CAV will be supporting the Multinational Force and Observers in Egypt. The MFO is an international peacekeeping force overseeing the terms of the peace treaty between Egypt and Israel. The 29th IBCT will be deploying to Kosovo in support of Multinational Battle Group East Kosovo Forces (KFOR). KFOR\'s mission is to contribute to a safe and secure environment, support the international humanitarian effort, and the development of a stable, democratic, multi-ethnic and peaceful Kosovo, and support the development of the Kosovo Security Force. Photos: http://bit.ly/2BPCDW3

author: Governor David Ige
title: ANSWER: The separations are an inhumane answer for people desperately seeking a better life. I can‚Äôt imagine how terrifying it must be for the children to be in a strange land, separated from their family and not knowing when they‚Äôll be able to see them again. As for the tariffs on foreign goods, business people I talk with say they anticipate pervasive, higher prices on goods. The global supply chain means it‚Äôs rare to buy an American manufactured product that has no foreign materials, so the costs will be passed on to consumers. Read more of August\'s Capitol Connection newsletter: http://bit.ly/2vpi8t1Subscribe to our monthly newsletter: http://1.usa.gov/23jRyto#HIGov #HINews #CapitolConnection #KeepFamiliesTogether

title: People IN HAWAII live on the streets, kids IN HAWAII live in poverty, the cost of living IN HAWAII are causing Hawaiis to leave their homes. A rail project going off the rails, streets that are almost undrivable, crumbling infrastructure and bursting pipes, inadequate shelter space for disasters.  Yet you find the time to point the finger on a topic you are ill informed on.First this us policy was followed by Obama, Bush and Clinton. When someone crosses our boarder it is an illegal act. Those with criminal histories are jailed.. so you want what exactly to be done with the children? Put in jail with them? No, they are separated. Sex trade trafficing of children is massive on the boarder... those that can not prove a parental relationship are separated. Kids are used as drug mules, as beggers as pickpockets. The boarder is a place where bad things happen. They are not long lines of happy families...rape of kids is common, starvation, abuse. What is more inhumane..to ignore the problems or separate the kids? By the way..most of the kids are kept with the parents if no problems found. So who pays for your generous spirit? Hawaii? The US gvmt? To a small extent but the boarder states do. The illegals are given a court day..that they never show up for and the boarder states pay the welfare portion and education VERY EXPENSIVE.   I have an idea..fix the massive problems in your own backyard..then actually go to the boarder and learn about all that is going on there. Then have an informed opinion and a plan you personally can do to help. No, not increase  the already over taxed and burdened Hawaii residents. I did not vote for you because you have no plan to effectively address the issues here. You tax instead of reduce the budget. So tell me...what do you say to someone from outside critical of your poor management of one of the most abundent and beautiful states in the country... probably..but out...

title: New funding from the Federal Aviation Administration will greatly assist our Airports Division in expediting needed improvements that will provide more jobs for Hawai‚Äòi residents and better serve our visitors.Hawai ªi airports are to receive $24.1 million for improvement projects at the Daniel K. Inouye International Airport, Ellison Onizuka Kona International Airport at Keahole, and the Kalaeloa Airport (John Rodgers Field). The grants are as follows:‚Ä¢ $12 million for Daniel K. Inouye International Airport to rebuild an aircraft apron. Aprons are areas where aircrafts park, load and unload cargo and passengers, or are refueled.‚Ä¢ $10 million for Ellison Onizuka Kona International at Keahole to build an Aircraft Rescue and Fire Fighting (ARFF) training facility.‚Ä¢ $2.1 million for Kalaeloa Airport (John Rodgers Field) to repair a runway.The FAA will also award grants to Hilo International Airport, Kahului Airport, Molokai Airport, and Lanai Airport to acquire ARFF vehicles.  For more details visit: http://bit.ly/2LBL0nEHawaii Department of Transportation #HIGov #HINews

title: Most Hawaii State Department of Education schools began formally transitioning this week to a SchoolMessenger text-messaging system that will allow schools to mass message parents via text message, email and phone calls with important school updates. SchoolMessenger is a communication platform used to deliver text messages to mobile phones with important information about events, school closings, safety alerts and other important information. Approximately 200 schools statewide currently use SchoolMessenger.Parents can enroll and download the app at www.schoolmessenger.com More info: http://bit.ly/2Lz7Psdüì∏:SchoolMessenger
description: Most Hawaii State Department of Education schools began formally transitioning this week to a SchoolMessenger text-messaging system that will allow schools to mass message parents via text message, email and phone calls with important school updates. SchoolMessenger is a communication platform used to deliver text messages to mobile phones with important information about events, school closings, safety alerts and other important information. Approximately 200 schools statewide currently use SchoolMessenger.Parents can enroll and download the app at www.schoolmessenger.com More info: http://bit.ly/2Lz7Psdüì∏:SchoolMessenger

author: Governor David Ige
title: Signed a supplementary proclamation to extend relief for disaster damages resulting from #HurricaneLane.While the hurricane weakened rapidly on Friday, Aug. 24, the storm‚Äôs moisture was spread over a greater area and resulted in prolonged periods of slow moving, heavy rain that continues to impact the state. In addition, high winds from the storm spread and expanded wildfires in the County of Maui and the City and County of Honolulu. The supplemental proclamation issued today is effective through Oct. 27, 2018. I issued the first emergency proclamation for Hurricane Lane on August 21, 2018. The request for a Presidential Disaster Declaration for the State of Hawai‚Äòi was approved on August 22, 2018.Supplementary Proclamation can be found here: http://bit.ly/2LAJDFVHonolulu County, Hawaii

title: Suggestion when Hawaii rebuilds (builds) sidewalks it should use volcanic rock with white stone.   In Portugal\'s Azore Islands capitol city of San Miguel, there are these type of sidewalks.   Each street has its own pattern of volcanic rock and stone.  The cobblestone like sidewalks are beautiful and last a long time.   They would be especially nice in parks and at resorts.   It would add to the charm of the Big lsland.   Hawaii would be the perfect place for volcanic rock sidewalks.

author: Governor David Ige
title: Dreams do come true and Kauai Habitat for Humanity helped make dreams of home ownership a reality for Phrystal Bacio, Shawntel Yadao and Eileen ‚ÄúMele‚Äù DeCosta. Congratulations to the new homeowners. Your efforts represent a wise investment in your future and demonstrate that with hard work and dedication, anything is possible. I extend my deepest appreciation to Kaua ªi Habitat for Humanity for helping individuals and families make their dreams of homeownership come true. You provide hope for hard-working families and bring people together to build homes and communities. Mahalo to all the partners who have helped these individuals on their journey to homeownership. Your efforts inspire us and give us hope that future generations will have a place they can choose to call home.For more information on this organization, visit: http://kauaihabitat.org/#HIGov #Kauai

author: Governor David Ige
title: "Farm to table‚Äù sounds fresh and appealing ‚Äî like going to your nearest farmer‚Äôs market ‚Äî but how many of us really know the hard work it takes to grow food? So when I set doubling local food production as one of my administration‚Äôs goals, skeptics wondered, ‚ÄúIs that even possible?‚Äù The answer is yes, say state agriculture officials ‚Äî with the right combination of available land and water, public-private investment, more support for current and future farmers, and new technology, such as high-tech, climate-controlled greenhouses on a scale that can make a difference for diversified ag.It‚Äôs a complex matrix of pieces and a far cry from the days when large plantations took care of everything ‚Äî from housing the workforce to quality assurance and distribution. Increasing local production includes supporting current growers as well as planning for a new kind of farming that relies less on back-breaking labor and more on ‚Äúsmart‚Äù technology to increase productivity. Determined farmers, aquaculture entrepreneurs and ag innovators are working with the state to increase Hawai‚Äòi‚Äôs food security, but they need more support. ‚ÄúCurrently, only 15 percent of food consumed in Hawai‚Äòi is actually produced here. We need to move island agriculture from the plantation era into the 21st century. That means combining sustainable practices with new technology to help current small farmers and attract a new generation of growers. Continue reading here: http://bit.ly/2okFfll Learn more about Hawai ªi‚Äôs Sustainable Initiative:  http://bit.ly/2k8ABESRead more of August\'s Capitol Connection newsletter: http://bit.ly/2vpi8t1Subscribe to our monthly newsletter: http://1.usa.gov/23jRyto#HIGov #HINews #CapitolConnection #SustainableHawaiiHawaii Department of Agriculture

title: Doubling farm products by 2020 is  admirable. Locally grown, raised and made products are of the finest and highest quality! Health conscience consumers are willing to pay a higher price for fresh organic goods! Rules, regulations, and laws from federal and state governments in the guise of the environment, food and health safety,  record keeping and reporting requirements have made farming a bureaucratic nightmare! Start by cutting the red tape, over regulation is the reason many family farms have shuttered their doors and young people shy away from farming as a way of life.

title: My administration has taken action on several fronts to make the transition to diversified agriculture possible, including:      ‚Ä¢ Preserving thousands of acres of prime agricultural land statewide for food production and coordinating water-related policies‚Ä¢ Providing farmers and aquaculture operators with $8.1 million in loans and state long-term leases‚Ä¢ Developing public-private partnerships for greater capital investment ‚Ä¢ Encouraging new farmers through business incubators and ag tech to help them become more productive‚Ä¢ Building community awareness through farm-to-table movements and the ‚ÄòAina Pono, farm-to-school program‚Ä¢ Revitalizing dairy, egg and livestock production as well as employing new greenhouse technology and sustainable practicesLearn more at http://bit.ly/2okFfll Sustainable Hawai ªi Initiative: http://bit.ly/2k8ABESAugust Capitol Connection newsletter: http://bit.ly/2vpi8t1Subscribe to my monthly newsletter: http://1.usa.gov/23jRyto#HIGov #HINews #CapitolConnection #SustainableHawaiiHawaii Department of Agriculture

What else is planned for the next few years?  Are there other initiatives targeting healthy nutrition in the pediatric population? If not, how do we get this started?

title: Check out North Shore EVP, the first GroupGAP organization in Hawaii. For local goods to get into the marketplace they need to be food safety certified. GroupGAP makes this easier for small farmers. Hawaii\'s land and other costs make it unlikely that farmers will scale up much, or that big farm operations will come in. Small scale farms can meet our needs but only when they work together.  And we need local distributors to get on board with this too. Please support us by following us on social media, and see our website nsevp.org!

title: Established in May 2016, the Joint Task Force on Rat Lungworm Disease is announcing new preliminary guidelines for the clinical management of rat lungworm disease. The new guidelines may be used by Hawai‚Äòi physicians immediately and provide clear diagnosis, treatment, and management guidance for timely identification and care for patients who have contracted the disease. ‚ÄúOne of the top priorities of the Joint Task Force has been to develop sound, evidence-based guidelines for physicians to use in diagnosing and treating angiostrongyliasis,‚Äù said Kenton Kramer, Ph.D., chair of the Joint Task Force and associate professor of the Department of Tropical Medicine, Medical Microbiology and Pharmacology with the University of Hawai‚Äòi John A. Burns School of Medicine. ‚ÄúThe Clinical Subcommittee, made up of expert physicians and specialists from across the state, spent the last year researching and consulting with national and international specialists on the disease to carefully craft the new guidelines.‚Äù Continue reading: http://bit.ly/2MChhQWHelpful prevention tips: http://bit.ly/2opr26süì∏: State of Hawaii Department of Health-Disease Outbreak Control Division #HIGov #HINews #RatLungwormDisease

title: Absolutely have to include fish in that goal. Unlike livestock, wild-caught fish feed themselves. No need to produce a resource or set aside areas to feed and raise them.Develop regulations to protect near-shore habitat from runoff and other pollution and damage. Add artificial reefs in certain areas to increase habitat.Support commercial and non-commercial fishing -- develop "active management" to ensure sustainability instead of closing off places. Open Kaupulehu and establish seasonal fishing, and require free public access.Open the bottomfish restricted areas that peer-reviewed science has shown to be ineffective.Ensure public access to all shoreline fishing areas.Restore old Hawaiian fishponds to produce mullet and other fish. Those ponds existed on a combination of natural systems that didn\'t require the fish to be fed. Again, they mostly fed themselves.
description: Absolutely have to include fish in that goal. Unlike livestock, wild-caught fish feed themselves. No need to produce a resource or set aside areas to feed and raise them.Develop regulations to protect near-shore habitat from runoff and other pollution and damage. Add artificial reefs in certain areas to increase habitat.Support commercial and non-commercial fishing -- develop "active management" to ensure sustainability instead of closing off places. Open Kaupulehu and establish seasonal fishing, and require free public access.Open the bottomfish restricted areas that peer-reviewed science has shown to be ineffective.Ensure public access to all shoreline fishing areas.Restore old Hawaiian fishponds to produce mullet and other fish. Those ponds existed on a combination of natural systems that didn\'t require the fish to be fed. Again, they mostly fed themselves.

title: We also really need to crack down of feral cats and the people that feed them. They leave extra food that also feed the rat and mongoose. Plus, the amount of liter they leave behind is endless. After reading an article about our endangered Hawaiian Monk Seals being infected and killed from being in contact with cat feces, this really should be moved apon quickly before our monk seals are wiped out before most people are even aware. Dogs also contract RLW disease, and can easily carry infected material into a personal car, bring the disease home with them on their fur. Signs to keep dogs off beaches where turtles and Hawaiian Monk Seals have been seen are daily ignored. WHY? How about really inforcing the laws we have in place that could actually take a bite out of the spread of RLW before it gets out of control!    HELP NOW!

author: Governor David Ige
title: Suicide is the leading cause of fatal injuries in Hawai‚Äòi for people ages 15 to 44 and is the ninth leading cause of all deaths in the state. From 2013 to 2017, 926 Hawai‚Äòi residents died from suicide. On average, one person dies by suicide every two days in the state.  A series of community events across the state during National Suicide Prevention Month in September aims to raise public awareness about the topic of suicide and the impact of suicides in Hawai‚Äòi as well as to connect survivors with helpful services.For anyone experiencing difficult or suicidal thoughts, or anyone who knows someone who is, call the Crisis Line of Hawai‚Äòi at 832-3100 (Oahu), 1-800-753-6879 (Neighbor Islands), the National Suicide Hotline at 1-800-273-TALK (8255), and message the Crisis Text Line at 741741. Resources are available 24 hours every day. More information about suicide prevention may be found at http://health.hawaii.gov/injuryprevention/home/suicide-prevention/information/.National Suicide Prevention Month activities are planned statewide in September. A list can be found at http://bit.ly/2PSK1mx #SuicidePrevention #HIGov #HINews State of Hawaii Department of Health-Disease Outbreak Control Division

title: Hawai ªi has a bold energy agenda ‚Äì to achieve 100 percent clean energy in the electricity sector by the year 2045. That‚Äôs why we are pleased to recognize, Hyatt Regency Waikiki Beach Resort and Spa for its energy efficiency and renewable energy achievements. We appreciate the Hyatt Regency Waikiki Beach Resort and Spa\'s bold steps to reduce, reuse and recycle; conserve Hawai ªi‚Äôs natural resources; and educate employees and customers about the importance of ‚Äúgreen‚Äù business practices.  It is important for #Hawaii to remain a leader in clean energy and sustainability at a time when leadership in these areas at the federal level is lacking. title: Who is going to farm the land?   Until we provide low cost loans to enable new farmers to get land, we\'re screwed.  Programs like GoFarm Hawaii can train lots of potential new farmers but until they can get land and help getting the resources to start farming, we\'ll still be importing lots of produce.  Only people with the economic means to afford the higher cost of local produce will buy it.  If we make it organic, the higher costs of the organic produce, we price even more people out.
description: Who is going to farm the land?   Until we provide low cost loans to enable new farmers to get land, we\'re screwed.  Programs like GoFarm Hawaii can train lots of potential new farmers but until they can get land and help getting the resources to start farming, we\'ll still be importing lots of produce.  Only people with the economic means to afford the higher cost of local produce will buy it.  If we make it organic, the higher costs of the organic produce, we price even more people out.

title: I humbly ask that you along with the Hawaii State legislature draft a law this coming session that restores #NetNeutrality.  With all of the wild fires set off here on Maui and the threat from major internet providers to skim back on  viable data services to not only emergency response personnel, but to the general public as well.I ask that you follow what the State of California\'s State legislature drafted and have it implemented here in the State of Hawaii.We can\'t afford to have companies skim back on a viable service during times of Civil Emergencies like Verizon did to the State of California fire fighters and law enforcement in the on-going fire storm they\'re having.  Many California citizens too had their services skimmed away.Please take this issue very seriously and enact a law that allows for a FREE, uninterrupted, and skim free internet service for Hawaii\'s citizens and emergency response personnel.Mahalo for your time with this matter and I look forward to hearing back from you Gov. Ige and Lt. Gov. Josh Green.

Ige and Lt. Gov. Josh Green.

author: Governor David Ige
title: Pleased to see programs geared toward innovative environmental projects where students can make an impact on their school and communities. Students who want to help their schools or communities go green now have a chance to earn funding to back their big ideas. Conservation and education nonprofit Kupu, in partnership with Kokua Hawaii Foundation, is launching its third annual Hawai‚Äòi Youth Sustainability Challenge mini-grant program, which supports student-led environmental initiatives.Applications are now open and due Oct. 19. Students in grades 6-12 from public, private, and charter schools statewide are encouraged to apply.Last school year, the program provided a total of $17,525 in mini-grants ranging from $150 to $1,000 to 22 student teams across 20 schools. Projects included custom-designed recycling bins, aquaponics systems, native plant subscription boxes, and an alternative fuel vehicle show, among many other creative environmental initiatives. For more information on Hawai‚Äòi Youth Sustainability Challenge or to apply, visit kupuhawaii.org/hysc/.See the states Sustainable Hawaii Initiative at http://bit.ly/2k8ABES#HIGov #SustainableHawaii

author: Governor David Ige
title: The shortage of teachers in Hawai ªi is a concern, and I am hopeful that the Troops to Teachers federal program and grant of $600K to the Hawai ªi State Department of Education will help.The Troops to Teachers program (http://bit.ly/2Ndec9H) was established in 1993 to help place transitioning service members into K-12 teaching positions around the country. It also offers financial assistance to help them meet state teacher licensing requirements and incentive pay to teach in hard-to-staff areas like Hawai ªi. The DOE will use its Troops to Teachers grant to establish a full-time position to recruit military veterans. #HIGov #HINews

title: We all know paying teachers a livable wage will go far. Cut down on the administration. Too many people pushing paper who are disconnected from what our keiki need. The DOE has been missing out on MILLION$ of federal dollars by failing to hire licensed related service providers. Teachers need support. We need long term solutions. In my experience when people come to Hawaii they are not well equipped for the horrid conditions in our DOE, the heat in our schools, the size of our classrooms and many struggle without family and friends nearby. Why aren‚Äôt we listening to our local and national experts instead of always chasing a ‚Äúnew innovative‚Äù idea that flops fast? #TeamTupola #VoteTupola #HI4PublicEd

title: My daughter, leilani misajon, applied to work as an educator/assistant in keaau, where her grandmother lives, and where she\'s been, and is on her way again, to visit. She\'s French, and it seems the DOE doesn\'t do the paperwork needed to hire people from other countries, so she\'s applied for a greencard and is keeping her fingers crossed. It\'s a bit frustrating, as a friend of hers, English but living in France, has had her own paperwork done to go and work at Disneyland....yeah, Disney over needed teachers.

title: I could not get my Massachusetts teaching license reciprocated when I moved here in 2013. I sat in the pool of applicants waiting to be processed. We actually created legislation and licensed an entire profession of behavior analysts more quickly than my teaching application was processed. I am now a Licensed Behavior Analyst (#1), but unfortunately my teaching licensed has since lapsed. Such a disgrace. Fix our broken systems. #FelixNumberTwo The next #FelixConsentDecree is on you.

author: Governor David Ige
title: Congratulations to Waianae\'s Asa Stevens, Hawai‚Äòi‚Äôs latest World Champion. Asa defeated England\'s Ivan Prince for the Gold medal in Budapest, Hungary last Friday, and became the first flyweight Youth World Champion for Team USA since 2014. He is only the second world amateur champion ever from Hawai‚Äòi.  Waipahu‚Äôs Brian Viloria did it in 1999 and later went on to the Olympics and a successful professional career.  All of Hawai‚Äòi will be behind your journey as you pursue the 2020 Olympics in Tokyo.

author: Governor David Ige
title: The ‚ÄòAina Pono Hawai‚Äòi State Farm to School program has earned five-stars from some of its toughest customers: the students. ‚ÄúWho wouldn‚Äôt want fresh, locally grown fruits, vegetables and beef instead of canned food?‚Äù said one high schooler. Thanks to a public-private partnership spearheaded by the Lieutenant Governor‚Äôs office, the pilot project that began in the Kohala district has expanded to Mililani High School, Mililani Uka and Mililani Waena elementary schools. ‚ÄúThe students and administration of Mililani High School gave ‚ÄòAina Pono high marks,‚Äù said Lt. Governor Doug Chin. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôve tasted the difference,  and their excitement is spreading to other schools.‚ÄùChin and others see the program as a step toward my goal of doubling local food production and improving food security for the entire state. It‚Äôs a win-win for local farmers to expand demand for their goods while providing healthier meals for students. "We plan to expand the program to other schools and continue the ‚ÄòHarvest of the Month‚Äô to highlight more local foods,‚Äù said Albert Scales, the Department of Education‚Äôs food services branch administrator.Private funders who have helped make the program possible include Ulupono Initiative, The Kohala Center, HMSA Foundation, Johnson ‚ÄòOhana Charitable Foundation, Kaiser Permanente, The Dorrance Family Foundation, and the Hawai‚Äòi Appleseed Center. It also recently received a $100,000 grant from the U.S. Department of Agriculture for expansion and training. Learn more about my Sustainable Hawaii Initiative and progress on doubling food production at http://bit.ly/2k8ABESRead more of August\'s Capitol Connection newsletter: http://bit.ly/2vpi8t1

title: Every two seconds, someone in the United States needs blood. One blood donation can potentially save up to three lives. In order to meet the needs of Hawai ªi patients, the Blood Bank of Hawaii will need at least 200 blood donors daily. Their work and your blood saves lives every day, and so, the state of Hawai ªi would like to recognize September 5, 2018 as the Hawai ªi Blood Donation Day. I encourage you to make an appointment to donate blood to help save a life. Please visit, www.bbh.org to find the nearest Donor Center. Mahalo.See proclamation at: http://bit.ly/2wMsHHR#HIGov #HINews #SaveaLife

author: Governor David Ige
title: As the only island state in the nation, Hawai ªi is already feeling the impacts of climate change. More extreme high tides and record high levels of flooding. . . eroding shorelines, coral bleaching and threatened watersheds and native forests. My administration is taking climate change seriously.The Hawai‚Äòi Climate Change Mitigation and Adaptation Commission (Climate Commission) at its regular quarterly meeting yesterday adopted a series of recommendations and finalized a mission statement to help guide Hawai‚Äòi‚Äôs response to the impacts of climate change. The Climate Commission is led by the Hawaii DLNR (Department of Land and Natural Resources) Chair and the Director of the State Office of Planning and includes members from key state and county agencies. The group‚Äôs mission statement formalized and approved at the meeting is as follows:‚ÄúHawai ªi‚Äôs Climate Commission recognizes the urgency of climate threats and the need to act quickly. It promotes ambitious, climate-neutral, culturally responsive strategies for climate change adaptation and mitigation in a manner that is Clean, Equitable & Resilient.‚ÄùThe recommended strategies or steps agreed upon by the Climate Commission include:‚Ä¢ Support legislation for disclosure for private property and public offerings located in areas with potential exposure to sea level rise. ‚Ä¢ Request all new development, redevelopment and modifications be directed away from beach areas.‚Ä¢ Urge counties to incorporate the 3.2 ft. sea level rise exposure area (SLR-XA) into their general and development plans.‚Ä¢ Encourage agencies and non-governmental utility providers to identify and prioritize assets within the 3.2 ft SLR-XA or more as described in the State‚Äôs Sea Level Rise report, identify adaptation measures, and to provide a status update on this activity annually to the Climate Commission.‚Ä¢ Support legislation that funds State programs to meet mitigation goals, and to bring resources to assist in planning and implementation for sea level rise and other climate related impacts.The next quarterly meeting of the Climate Commission is scheduled for Tuesday, Nov. 27, 2018 from 1 to 4 p.m. at the Board of Land and Natural Resources meeting room, Kalanimoku Building, 1151 Punchbowl Street in Honolulu.  All meetings are open to the public.Find information on all of the efforts the state is taking to address climate change at Hawai‚Äòi Climate Change Portal: http://climate.hawaii.gov/#HIGov #HINews #ClimateChange #StillIn

author: Governor David Ige
title: Climate change is real. Hawai ªi became the first state to adopt a law aligning with the Paris agreement to combat climate change. Sea level rise is already having an impact on beaches, roadways and homes near the shoreline. Hawai ªi could expect to see a sea level rise of 3.2 feet by 2100, if not sooner, flooding 6,500 structures in the Islands and displacing nearly 20,000 residents, according to the 2017 Hawaii Sea Level Rise Vulnerability and Adaptation Report via Hawaii DLNR (Department of Land and Natural Resources). (Report: http://bit.ly/2Qc08fh)As a result, we face difficult land-use decisions, and requiring an analysis of sea level rise before beginning construction is just plain common sense. Our state must plan for these changes and so in June, I  21 signed House Bill 2106 which requires a sea level rise analysis in environmental impact statements and assessments to include an analysis of sea level rise and climate related impact before building projects.Reducing Hawai ªi‚Äôs carbon footprint is also a priority, and we took steps to pledge to be carbon-neutral by 2045, the same year we expect to reach our goal of generating 100 percent of our electricity from clean, renewable sources. House Bill 2182 and House Bill 1986 were signed this past June to create a framework for a carbon offset program that allows for carbon credit throughs global carbon sequestration protocols. We see tremendous potential for restoration, protection and management of forest areas in Hawai ªi to offer cost-efficient climate change mitigation. That‚Äôs why this framework for capturing carbon through reforestation and carbon farming is an important step forward.Hawai ªi is leading the charge in combating climate change, and I hope other states and country will do the same. #WeAre100 #Stillin Watch bill signing video: https://youtu.be/OnPTZkgnlc4?t=42s#TBT #HIGov #ClimateChange

title: Asked the President of the United States to declare a major disaster for the State of Hawai‚Äòi as a result of the impacts from Hurricane Lane. This includes floods and wildfires that occurred as a result of the hurricane, from Aug. 22 to Aug. 29, 2018. The magnitude and severity of the disaster requires federal assistance. This exceeds the state‚Äôs response capability and it has impacted local governments.Requesting the authorization of the Public Assistance Grant Program, the full complement of Individual Assistance programs, and the Small Business Administration (SBA) Disaster Assistance program for Hawai‚Äòi County and Maui County. In addition, Gov. Ige is requesting the Hazard Mitigation Grant program statewide, and 100 percent federal funding for a 72-hour period in the initial days of the disaster.Click to view letter requesting for Presidential Disaster Declaration, and photos of damages: http://bit.ly/2MTMBe6

author: Governor David Ige
title: This confirms what we‚Äôve known all along; protecting Hawai ªi‚Äôs forest will also protect the coral reef ecosystem. In 2016, I announced at the International Union for the Conservation of Nature World Conservation Congress the launch of the Sustainable Hawai ªi Initiative (http://bit.ly/2k8ABES). In Hawai ªi, our koa- ª≈çhi ªa forests cover nearly half of our islands and provide habitat for forest life and watersheds that produce fresh, clean water for our people. That‚Äôs why I‚Äôve committed to protecting 30% of our highest priority watersheds by 2030. Our reefs provide habitat for spectacular marine life, and feed us. That‚Äôs why I‚Äôm committed to effectively managing 30% of our nearshore ocean waters by 2030. My commitment to protect our forests and coral reefs is not enough. This past June, I signed into law Senate Bill 2571, now Act 104, banning the sale and distribution of sunscreens that contain oxybenzone and octinoxate which are toxic to coral reefs. We are leading the world in this safe reef movement and I hope it will inspire other states and countries to do the same. We have a responsibility to our land and water and my administration will continue to work to protect them so that they can begin to heel. Will you ask for safe reef sunscreens?#30x30 #HIGov

title: To clarify my position, I\'m a skeptic, not a denier. And more importantly, a skeptic of the C02 AGW. To my knowledge, the numbers have never added up. And to my dismay, many fellow scientists have abandoned their scientific curiosity by simply adhering to the C02 mantra. I don\'t deny that the earth is getting warmer over the millennia, after all, we are only 10k years out of an ice age that lasted over 100k years(what caused the ice age in the first place?). My fear is that without healthy skepticism from the scientific community, we may miss the other important reasons for climate change. As it is now, we may be undergoing another solar minimum after a very minimal solar maximum. I\'d like to know if this affects earth\'s climate. How about the deciduous forests pumping out large amounts (550 million tons )of isoprenes that react with H20 vapor forming epoxides each year. Does the plastic debris fields in our oceans affect oceanic pH and alter climate? Is there a connection between cosmic rays and cloud formation and climate change?Remember that man creates 30-40 billion tons of C02 each year (the US accounts for 20%) that goes into an atmosphere that already has 3,600 billion tons of C02.  In other words, man creates only 1% or less of all C02 already in our atmosphere.  And terrestial(land) plants absorb 450 billion tons of C02 each year, far greater than what man produces, and it actually only represents 15% of all plant C02 absorption...85% from oceanic photosynthetic lifeforms(or absorption of 2,550 billion tons of C02 each year).  C02 is a very dynamic gas, it is not a stagnant molecule in our environment.Also, the biggest greenhouse gas contributor is water vapor and clouds. Maybe upwards of 90% or more. But we don\'t count water vapor effects. Why is that? It leaves us with only 10% or less for all the other greenhouse gases to affect our "warming". Although, without water vapor and clouds, we\'re left with numbers that look alarming but confusing due to such wide ranges... CO2(all 3,600 billion tons) accounts for only 0.9-2.6 points (of that 10%),CH4 causing 0.4-0.9 points(of that 10%) O3 at 0.3-0.7(etc), and others like NOx, CFCs, SF6(sulfur hexafluoride). Hence my skeptism of AGW. Too many questions.

And to my dismay, many fellow scientists have abandoned their scientific curiosity by simply adhering to the C02 mantra. I don\'t deny that the earth is getting warmer over the millennia, after all, we are only 10k years out of an ice age that lasted over 100k years(what caused the ice age in the first place?). My fear is that without healthy skepticism from the scientific community, we may miss the other important reasons for climate change. As it is now, we may be undergoing another solar minimum after a very minimal solar maximum. I\'d like to know if this affects earth\'s climate. How about the deciduous forests pumping out large amounts (550 million tons )of isoprenes that react with H20 vapor forming epoxides each year. Does the plastic debris fields in our oceans affect oceanic pH and alter climate? Is there a connection between cosmic rays and cloud formation and climate change?Remember that man creates 30-40 billion tons of C02 each year (the US accounts for 20%) that goes into an atmosphere that already has 3,600 billion tons of C02.  In other words, man creates only 1% or less of all C02 already in our atmosphere.  And terrestial(land) plants absorb 450 billion tons of C02 each year, far greater than what man produces, and it actually only represents 15% of all plant C02 absorption...85% from oceanic photosynthetic lifeforms(or absorption of 2,550 billion tons of C02 each year).  C02 is a very dynamic gas, it is not a stagnant molecule in our environment.Also, the biggest greenhouse gas contributor is water vapor and clouds. Maybe upwards of 90% or more. But we don\'t count water vapor effects. Why is that? It leaves us with only 10% or less for all the other greenhouse gases to affect our "warming". Although, without water vapor and clouds, we\'re left with numbers that look alarming but confusing due to such wide ranges... CO2(all 3,600 billion tons) accounts for only 0.9-2.6 points (of that 10%),CH4 causing 0.4-0.9 points(of that 10%) O3 at 0.3-0.7(etc), and others like NOx, CFCs, SF6(sulfur hexafluoride). Hence my skeptism of AGW. Too many questions.

author: Governor David Ige
title: Today, I signed an emergency proclamation (http://bit.ly/2O2cUeL) that will provide relief for disaster damages, losses and suffering caused by #HurricaneOlivia. Even if Olivia arrives as a Tropical Storm, as predicted, Hawai‚Äòi is in danger of experiencing high winds, heavy rains, high surf, storm surges and flooding that threaten to harm communities and cause extensive damage to public and private property across the state. We‚Äôre monitoring this storm closely and taking steps now to ensure that we‚Äôre prepared for its impacts to the state. A tropical storm could bring heavy rain and flooding, especially in places that are saturated from previous storms. Now is the time to prepare. The proclamation declares the counties of Hawai‚Äòi, Maui, Kalawao, Kaua‚Äòi and the City and County of Honolulu disaster areas for the purpose of implementing emergency management functions. The proclamation also authorizes the expenditure of state monies as appropriated for the speedy and efficient relief of damages, losses, and suffering resulting from Hurricane Olivia. The emergency proclamation expires on September 17, 2018.#HIGov #HINews #PrepareNow

author: Governor David Ige
title: 11am Update: #Olivia continues to slowly move westward toward the state. A WSW turn is anticipated later today continuing into Tuesday. While some gradual weakening is still in the forecast, Olivia will likely be a strong tropical storm as it approaches Hawaii #hiwx Hurricane Olivia has weakened slightly late this morning with max sustained winds of 75mph. These hurricane force winds extends about 15 miles from the center, while the tropical storm force winds reach about 115 miles. Olivia is forecast to maintain hurricane strength over the next day or so before gradually weakening, likely moving over portions of the island chain as a strong tropical storm bringing the threat of high winds, high surf and storm surge, and heavy rain. Continue to monitor weather.gov/cphc for updates#HIGov #HINews

author: Governor David Ige
title: #HurricaneOlivia 2pm UPDATE: Olivia has become a Tropical Storm. Please keep in mind that the difference between a Category 1 and a Tropical Storm is only 5mph! The threat of damaging winds, flooding rain, high surf, and storm surge still remains. No change to watches/warnings. Don\'t let your guards down! üìöHawaii State Department of Education update: Effective Tuesday, Sept. 11, all afterschool activities and programs, including interscholastic athletic events and After-School Plus (A+) Programs, will be canceled on the Big Island and Maui County.The only school closure currently in effect Tuesday will be for Hana High and Elementary School.Families of students in charter schools are asked to contact their schools directly to learn about closures, or visit the Public Charter School Commission‚Äôs website at https://www.chartercommission.hawaii.gov/ More details: bit.ly/2x0FF4T____üèïÔ∏è Hawaii DLNR (Department of Land and Natural Resources) update: All Hawai‚Äòi island and Maui Nui lands under the jurisdiction of the DLNR Division of Forestry and Wildlife are closing at noon on Tuesday, Sept. 11, 2018. Closures include:Wai ªanapanapa State Park, Maui-Closing at 12:00 noon on 9/11Other Maui Nui Parks-Closing at regular closing times on 9/11Hawai‚Äòi island, East side parks-closing at 12:00 noon on T9/11Hawai‚Äòi island, West side parks-will be evaluated for closing as the storm approachesMore details: http://bit.ly/2N5T6KX____Hawaii Tourism Authority urges Hawaii‚Äôs visitors to listen to airline, hotel and tourism industry professionals. They are well-trained for handling situations involving severe weather and do an excellent job of looking out for and taking care of guests. For visitors currently in Hawaii or with confirmed trips to anywhere in the Hawaiian Islands in the coming weeks, HTA advises them to stay informed about Olivia and to contact their airlines, accommodations and activity providers to see if adjustments to travel plans are needed.More details: bit.ly/2QkZnAn___‚úàÔ∏è Five airlines servicing Hawaii have so far issued waivers for reservation change fees for customers traveling to or from parts of Hawaii due to Olivia: Hawaiian Airlines is waiving reservation change fees for travel to, from, within, and via Hawaii from Sept. 11-13United will waive fees for travel on Sept. 10-13Alaska Airlines - Honolulu Int\'l Airport HNL will waive fees from Sept. 10-12American Airlines from Sept. 10-13Delta Air Lines from Sept. 11-12.#hiwx #HIGov #HINews #Olivia #HurricaneOlivia

title: JUST A REMINDER: If you\'re evacuating to a hotel/motel & they say they DON\'T accept pets, don\'t be angry, calmly tell them that\'s against the law & after Hurricane Katrina Congress created The Pets Evacuation and Transportation Standards Act (PETS) to require states seeking Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) assistance to accommodate pets and service animals in their plans for evacuating residents facing disasters. üêïüêàüêï
